faqs.question: What is The Depositor Education and Awareness (DEA) Fund Scheme, 2014, and when did this Scheme come into effect?
faqs.answer: The Depositor Education and Awareness Fund (DEA Fund) Scheme, 2014 was formulated by the Reserve Bank of India under Section 26A of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949. The Scheme came into effect on May 24, 2014, upon its notification in the Official Gazette of India.

faqs.question: Which are the amounts credited to the DEA Fund?
faqs.answer: The amounts credited to the DEA Fund include credit balances in deposit accounts (savings, fixed, recurring, current), loan accounts after due appropriation, margin money against Letters of Credit, outstanding drafts and cheques, unadjusted NEFT balances, and other unclaimed amounts that have remained inactive for 10 years or more.

faqs.question: When are the above specified amounts credited to the DEA Fund?
faqs.answer: Banks must transfer unclaimed deposits to the DEA Fund on the last working day of the month following the completion of 10 years of inactivity. For example, deposits becoming due in April will be transferred in May.

faqs.question: Is interest accrued on such amounts also transferred to the DEA Fund?
faqs.answer: Yes, banks must transfer the entire amount, including accrued interest, to the DEA Fund at the time of transfer.

faqs.question: Can a customer or depositor claim a refund of their unclaimed amounts from the DEA Fund?
faqs.answer: Yes, depositors can claim their unclaimed amounts from their respective banks. The bank will process the refund along with applicable interest (if any) and then seek reimbursement from the DEA Fund maintained by RBI.

faqs.question: Is there a time limit for claiming the amount from the DEA Fund?
faqs.answer: No, there is no specific time limit for claiming a refund from the DEA Fund. However, depositors or legal heirs are encouraged to claim the amounts as soon as they become aware of them.

faqs.question: What is the procedure to claim from DEA Fund if a bank is under liquidation?
faqs.answer: Depositors must approach the Liquidator of the bank, who will process claims as per guidelines. If the deposit was insured by DICGC (up to ₹5 lakh), the Liquidator can claim an equivalent amount from the DEA Fund. If the claim exceeds ₹5 lakh, the excess amount will be reimbursed by the DEA Fund only after the Liquidator settles the depositor’s claim.

faqs.question: How does the claim process work if a bank under liquidation has deposits covered by DICGC?
faqs.answer: If a depositor had a claim of ₹4 lakh and DICGC insurance was available, the Liquidator would claim ₹4 lakh from the DEA Fund and transfer the amount to the depositor. If a depositor had a claim of ₹6 lakh, the Liquidator would claim ₹5 lakh from the DEA Fund and pay the remaining ₹1 lakh first before seeking reimbursement for the excess amount.

faqs.question: How does the claim process work if a bank under liquidation has deposits not covered by DICGC?
faqs.answer: For deposits not covered by DICGC, the Liquidator must first settle the depositor’s claim and then seek reimbursement from the DEA Fund.

faqs.question: As per Para 6 of the Guidelines on Default Loss Guarantee (DLG) in Digital Lending dated June 08, 2023, RE shall ensure that total amount of DLG cover on any outstanding portfolio which is specified upfront shall not exceed five per cent of the amount of that loan portfolio. How to ensure that the portfolio on which DLG has been given is specified upfront?
faqs.answer: The portfolio over which DLG can be offered shall consist of identifiable and measurable loan assets which have been sanctioned (the ‘DLG set’). This portfolio will remain fixed for the purpose of DLG cover and is not meant to be dynamic.

faqs.question: On which amount will the cap of five per cent be calculated?
faqs.answer: The cap is applicable on the total amount disbursed out of the DLG set at any given time.

faqs.question: In case DLG is invoked due to a default occurring in portfolio, can the subsequent recoveries made from the borrowers on the defaulted amount be added back to the DLG cover?
faqs.answer: No. DLG amount once invoked by the RE cannot be reinstated, including through loan recovery.

faqs.question: Is the name of the RE also required to be published along with the disclosure in terms of Para 11 of the Guidelines?
faqs.answer: No. Not required.

faqs.question: In case an RE functioning as an LSP is providing DLG, does it also need to have a Board approved policy?
faqs.answer: While the Guidelines mandate the REs accepting DLG cover to have a Board approved policy in place, the REs acting as DLG providers shall also put in place Board approved policy as a prudent measure.

faqs.question: Whether the guidelines on DLG are also applicable for loans sourced by REs under arrangements outside the scope of the Digital Lending Guidelines?
faqs.answer: No.

faqs.question: Whether DLG is permitted for loans arranged on the NBFC-P2P platforms?
faqs.answer: No. DLG is not permitted on loans arranged on NBFC-P2P platforms.

faqs.question: Para 12.3 of guidelines require a declaration from DLG provider, certified by the statutory auditor. Whether the same is required to be certified by the statutory auditor of the RE or the DLG provider?
faqs.answer: The declaration has to be certified by the statutory auditor of the DLG provider.

faqs.question: Whether REs are allowed to enter into DLG arrangements for credit cards as defined under Master Direction – Credit Card and Debit Card – Issuance and Conduct Directions, 2022?
faqs.answer: No. DLG arrangements for credit cards are not permitted.

faqs.question: Whether REs are allowed to enter into DLG arrangements for revolving credit facilities offered through Digital Lending channel?
faqs.answer: No.

faqs.question: In case the DLG provider is a Regulated Entity (RE), what will be the applicable capital requirement?
faqs.answer: RE providing DLG shall deduct full amount of the DLG which is outstanding from its capital.

faqs.question: Whether REs are allowed to enter into DLG arrangements for loans covered under any of the credit guarantee schemes of National Credit Guarantee Trustee Company Limited (NCGTC)?
faqs.answer: DLG arrangements are not permitted on the loans which are covered by the credit guarantee schemes administered by trust funds as specified under para 2 of Review of Prudential Norms – Risk Weights for Exposures guaranteed by Credit Guarantee Schemes (CGS) dated September 07, 2022, as amended from time to time.

faqs.question: What should a customer do if a credit card is issued without his/her consent (unsolicited card)?
faqs.answer: Card issuers are prohibited from issuing unsolicited credit cards and are required to seek prior and explicit consent from the customer before issuing a card. If the customer receives an unsolicited card, they should refrain from activating it or providing consent through OTP or any other means. The card issuer must close the credit card account without any cost to the customer within seven working days and notify the customer. The customer may also file a complaint with the card issuer and escalate it to the RBI Ombudsman.

faqs.question: Can a card be issued to other loan accounts such as overdraft facility, cash credit facility, working capital loan, etc.?
faqs.answer: Yes, credit cards can be customized to access limits available in different loan accounts, aligned with the terms and conditions of the concerned loan account. However, banks cannot issue debit cards to cash credit or loan accounts.

faqs.question: What can be considered as activation of a credit card?
faqs.answer: Customer-initiated actions such as PIN generation, modification of transaction control, Interactive Voice Response, recorded calls to customer care, or SMS may be considered as activation. If the card is not activated within 30 days from issuance, card issuers must seek OTP-based consent.

faqs.question: Can a credit card be considered as ‘used’ even if no financial transactions have been undertaken?
faqs.answer: Yes, non-financial activities such as statement generation, PIN change, and modification of transaction controls are considered as usage. Calls made to customer care for other reasons do not count towards card usage.

faqs.question: Whether consent for activation and closure of a business credit card can be obtained from the corporate/business entity instead of the cardholder?
faqs.answer: For business credit cards issued based on an application by a corporate or business entity, consent for activation and closure must be obtained from the principal account holder (corporate/business entity) unless otherwise specified in the agreement.

faqs.question: In case a cardholder makes partial payment, can a card issuer charge interest/levy late payment charges on the total amount due?
faqs.answer: Interest may be levied on the outstanding amount from the transaction date if the total amount due is not cleared by the due date. Late payment fees and other charges shall be levied only on the outstanding amount, not the total amount due.

faqs.question: Whether a credit card issuer can levy interest on unpaid taxes/levies/charges?
faqs.answer: No, card issuers shall not capitalize or levy interest on unpaid taxes, levies, or charges. This provision has been effective since October 1, 2022.

faqs.question: What transactions are eligible to be adjusted towards outstanding dues and which should be credited to the bank account of the cardholder?
faqs.answer: Refunds or reversed transactions before bill generation are adjusted with other debits. If a refund occurs after bill generation but before payment, it is adjusted towards the total amount due. If payment has already been made, explicit consent is required to adjust the refund; otherwise, it will be credited to the bank account.

faqs.question: Can a cardholder modify the billing cycle of a credit card to any date?
faqs.answer: Yes, the cardholder is allowed to modify the billing cycle at least once. Card issuers should provide this option through multiple channels such as helpline, email, IVR, internet banking, and mobile applications.

faqs.question: Can a card issuer allow a credit card to be used beyond the sanctioned credit limit and charge over-limit fees?
faqs.answer: Cardholders must provide explicit consent before using a credit card beyond the sanctioned limit. Without such consent, over-limit charges cannot be levied.

faqs.question: Whether interest, taxes, or any other charges can be considered for computing a cardholder’s credit limit usage for the purpose of levying over-limit charges?
faqs.answer: No, interest and other fees shall not be factored in for computing a cardholder’s credit limit usage or levying over-limit charges.

faqs.question: Whether the liability towards credit card dues lies only with the principal cardholder?
faqs.answer: Yes, the principal cardholder is solely responsible for dues. However, for international credit cards, payment responsibilities are governed by FEMA regulations.

faqs.question: Are card issuers required to provide an insurance cover on debit and credit cards?
faqs.answer: RBI has not mandated insurance on debit or credit cards. If an issuer offers insurance, relevant details must be recorded and disclosed in the card statement, along with contact information for claims.

faqs.question: Can a card issuer partner with more than one co-branding partner for a card?
faqs.answer: Yes.

faqs.question: Can a co-branding partner acting as a business correspondent (BC) or technology service provider access transaction data of a cardholder?
faqs.answer: No, a co-branding partner cannot access transaction data. Transaction-related information may be displayed in an encrypted form through the card issuer’s system but should not be accessed or stored by the co-branding partner.

faqs.question: Does deactivation/blocking of a credit card amount to closure of the card account?
faqs.answer: No, deactivation or blocking a credit card temporarily restricts transactions but does not terminate the account. Closure of a credit card account terminates the relationship between the cardholder and issuer, which must be completed within seven working days upon request.

faqs.question: What is the procedure for filing a complaint against a card issuer?
faqs.answer: Customers should first approach the card issuer. If the issue is unresolved within 30 days, they can file a complaint with the RBI Ombudsman through the online portal (https://cms.rbi.org.in) or by mailing a physical complaint to the Centralized Receipt and Processing Centre at RBI, Chandigarh.

faqs.question: Whether a Joint Account can be continued for family pension after death of a pensioner?
faqs.answer: Yes, the banks should not insist on opening of a new account in case of Central Government pensioner if the spouse in whose favour an authorization for family pension exists in the Pension Payment Order (PPO) is the survivor. The family pension should be credited to the existing account without opening a new account by the family pensioner for this purpose.

faqs.question: When is the pension credited to the pensioner's account by the paying branch?
faqs.answer: The pension paying banks credit the pension amount in the accounts of the pensioners based on the instructions given by the Pension Paying Authorities.

faqs.question: Can the pension paying bank recover the excess amount credited to the pensioner’s account?
faqs.answer: Agency banks are requested to seek guidance from respective Pension Sanctioning Authorities regarding the process to be followed for recovery of excess pension paid to the pensioners, if any. Where excess pension payment has arisen on account of mistakes committed by the bank, the amount paid in excess should be refunded to the Government in lump-sum immediately after detection of the same and without waiting for recovery of any amount from the pensioners.

faqs.question: Should acknowledgement be given by pension paying banks while accepting Life Certificates from pensioners?
faqs.answer: Yes, to alleviate the hardships faced by pensioners, agency banks were instructed to mandatorily issue duly signed acknowledgements. They were also requested to consider entering the receipt of life certificates in their CBS and issue a system generated acknowledgement which would serve the twin purpose of acknowledgement as well as real-time updation of records. Banks may provide digital acknowledgements in respect of digital life certificates submitted by the pensioners.

faqs.question: Can a pensioner withdraw pension from his/ her account when he/she is not able to sign or put thumb/toe impression or unable to be present in the bank?
faqs.answer: Yes, instructions have been issued by RBI to pension disbursing banks to allow withdrawal of pension by following certain procedures. If a pensioner is too ill to sign a cheque or unable to be physically present in the bank, or even unable to put their thumb impression due to a physical defect, agency banks may follow a procedure where independent witnesses, including a responsible bank official, verify the withdrawal. The responsible bank official should preferably be from the same branch where the pensioner holds the pension account.

faqs.question: How the payment of Dearness Relief at revised rate is to be paid to the pensioners?
faqs.answer: The pension paying agency banks have to revise the Dearness Relief based on the copies of government orders provided by government to them through post, fax, e-mails, or by accessing the information from the website of the concerned governments, and authorize their pension paying branches to make payments to the pensioners immediately.

faqs.question: Whether a pensioner is entitled for any compensation from the agency banks for delayed credit of pension/ arrears of pension?
faqs.answer: Yes, pension paying banks should compensate the pensioner for delay in crediting pension/ arrears thereof at a fixed interest rate of 8 per cent per annum for the delay after the due date of payment. This compensation should be credited to the pensioner's account automatically without any claim from the pensioner on the same day when the bank affords credit for revised pension/ pension arrears, in respect of all delayed pension payments made since October 1, 2008.

faqs.question: Certain aspects of Master Direction on Regulatory Framework for Microfinance Loans may require additional time for drafting of new policies, getting board-level approvals, making changes in technology systems, training of staff, etc. Whether the timeline for complete rollout of these directions may be extended, while keeping the effective date as April 1, 2022?
faqs.answer: The effective date of these directions is April 1, 2022. However, in view of implementation-related difficulties expressed by some regulated entities (REs), REs are advised to implement these directions completely at the earliest on best effort basis, but not later than October 1, 2022.

faqs.question: Whether all members of a household are mandatorily required to become borrowers of a microfinance loan?
faqs.answer: The directions require assessment of income and indebtedness at household level. There is no requirement of treating all members of the household as applicants/borrowers of a loan which can be provided to an individual member. Board-approved policies of REs may include the methodologies/operational frameworks to assess income and indebtedness of all members of the household.

faqs.question: Whether loans for consumption (i.e., for buying gadgets, meeting expenses on ceremonies, etc.) without collateral would be treated as microfinance loans?
faqs.answer: All collateral-free loans to individual/s belonging to low-income households, i.e., households having annual income up to ₹3,00,000 are treated as microfinance loans.

faqs.question: If a loan is backed by hypothecation of any security (gold, equipment, white goods, underlying assets etc.), will this loan be considered collateral-free and classified as a microfinance loan?
faqs.answer: Loans backed by hypothecation of any security shall not be treated as microfinance loans.

faqs.question: Whether the instructions related to limit of 50 per cent on monthly loan repayment obligations of a household as a percentage of monthly household income apply to non-microfinance loans given to low-income households?
faqs.answer: Yes, for providing a non-microfinance loan to a low-income household (as defined under the directions), it should be ensured that the limit of 50 per cent on monthly loan repayment obligations of a household as a percentage of monthly household income is not breached. In other words, the limit of 50 per cent shall include both microfinance as well as non-microfinance loans.

faqs.question: How should credit facilities not having an EMI feature be treated for arriving at total monthly repayment obligations of the household?
faqs.answer: Board-approved policies of REs should cover such operational aspects. One possible way could be to distribute the annualized repayment obligations over twelve months to estimate monthly outgo of the household towards debt repayment.

faqs.question: Can expected income from an asset/activity financed by a microfinance loan be included for estimation of household income?
faqs.answer: No.

faqs.question: What type of insurance charges are to be disclosed in the factsheet and included for computation of effective annualized interest rate? Whether charges related to non-credit products should also be provided in the factsheet?
faqs.answer: The insurance charges included in the factsheet are only for credit-linked insurance product as these charges are linked to the microfinance loan. A borrower would not have incurred these charges if he had not taken the loan. The factsheet should contain information related to only pricing of microfinance loans to keep it uncluttered. Disclosures related to other non-credit products should be provided separately from the factsheet.

faqs.question: Are REs allowed to review and revise interest rates applicable to existing loans during the loan tenure apart from cases of restructured loans?
faqs.answer: The directions are applicable to loans sanctioned on or after April 1, 2022. Accordingly, pricing of the existing loans of NBFC-MFIs i.e., sanctioned prior to April 1, 2022 shall continue to be as per the guidelines applicable as on March 31, 2022. Other REs were already free to decide pricing of loans sanctioned, they are allowed to review and revise interest rates applicable to the existing loans also, subject to compliance with the relevant guidelines.

faqs.question: Is the practice of calling a borrower before 9.00 am and after 6.00 pm being considered as harsh practice only for recovery of overdue loans or also for normal conduct of business?
faqs.answer: This clause is applicable only for recovery from borrowers having overdue loans. For other borrowers, REs can continue with the existing timing/process for business like group meetings, collection in regular accounts, etc. as per borrowers’ convenience.

faqs.question: Is there any specific reason for including a dedicated mechanism for redressal of recovery-related grievances when there is already a customer grievance redress mechanism?
faqs.answer: The purpose of having a dedicated redress mechanism for recovery-related grievances is that these grievances should be promptly addressed. Treating them as other complaints (e.g., operational issues) may result in delayed action. However, this does not imply that a separate redress mechanism for recovery-related grievances is being mandated. REs can restructure/re-organise the existing customer grievance redress mechanism to identify and promptly address recovery-related grievances.

faqs.question: What is the purpose of assessment of household expenses as provided under Annex-I on ‘Indicative Methodology for Household Income Assessment’? Does it mean that household income for computing the limit on loan repayment obligations of a household is the household income net of expenses?
faqs.answer: Annex I provides only an indicative methodology for assessment of household income, and REs are required to put in place a board-approved policy for household income assessment. References to household expenses and assessment of household profile are only for the purpose of validation of the household income reported by the borrowers.

faqs.question: Is the regulatory framework for microfinance loans applicable to all entities operating in the microfinance sector including trusts and societies?
faqs.answer: The regulatory framework for microfinance loans is applicable only to REs/entities as defined under para 2.14 and para 9.25 of the directions. However, it may be prudent for other lenders operating in the microfinance sector to follow these customer-centric directions.

faqs.question: What should a customer keep in mind while availing a microfinance loan?
faqs.answer: The customer should keep in mind, among others, the following: (a) There is no requirement of keeping any deposit/margin/collateral/primary security with the lender at any stage of the microfinance loan. (b) Lender is required to provide a loan card to the borrower with all necessary details. (c) Purchase of any non-credit products is purely voluntary. (d) Training provided by the lenders is free of cost.

faqs.question: What are the charges that a customer is required to pay for a microfinance loan?
faqs.answer: A customer is required to pay only those charges which are explicitly mentioned in the factsheet provided by the lender. There is no pre-payment penalty on microfinance loans. Penalty for delayed payment can be applied only on the overdue amount and not on the entire loan amount.

faqs.question: How can a borrower find about the current interest rates being charged on the microfinance loans?
faqs.answer: RBI has made it mandatory for lenders to display the minimum, maximum, and average interest rates charged on microfinance loans in all their offices, in the literature issued by them, and on their website.

faqs.question: Does the circular apply to all loan products or only to Personal Loans?
faqs.answer: The circular is applicable to all equated periodic instalment based personal loans only. The circular is not applicable to other types of loans. The Reserve Bank circular DBR.No.BP.BC.99/08.13.100/2017-18 on “XBRL Returns – Harmonization of Banking Statistics” dated January 04, 2018 may be referred for the definition of personal loans.

faqs.question: In terms of paragraph 2(i) and paragraph 4 of the circular, REs have been advised to communicate to the borrowers the impact of interest rate reset on EMI, in a floating rate personal loan, both at the time of sanction as well as during the tenure of the loan. In this context, when and at what frequency shall REs communicate with the borrower? What will be the content of the communication?
faqs.answer:
Communications to borrowers envisaged in the circular are:
(a) At the time of sanction:
  (i) Annualised rate of interest/Annual Percentage Rate (APR), as applicable, shall be disclosed in the Key Fact Statement (KFS) and the loan agreement.
  (ii) The possible impact of change in benchmark interest rate on the loan.
(b) During the tenure of the loan:
  (i) Any increase in the EMI/tenor on account of the external benchmark rate shall be communicated.
  (ii) Quarterly statements shall be provided disclosing at the minimum, the principal and interest recovered till date, EMI amount, number of EMIs left, and annualized rate of interest for the tenor of the loan.

faqs.question: In terms of paragraph 4 of the circular, REs have been advised to intimate the different options available to address the increase in EMI in a rising interest rate scenario. What are the different options available to borrowers during a rising interest rate cycle in respect of equated installment based personal loans?
faqs.answer:
Whenever there is a reset of interest rates for an entire class of borrowers in a particular loan category, say home loan, due to an increase in the reference benchmark, the RE shall provide the following options to the borrowers:
(a) Either enhancement in EMI or elongation of number of EMIs, keeping the EMI unchanged or a combination of both options;
(b) Switch to fixed interest rate for the remaining portion of the loan; and
(c) To prepay, either in part or in full, at any point during the residual tenor of the loan.

faqs.question: One of the options allowed to the borrower vide paragraph 2(ii) of the circular is the option to switch from a floating interest rate loan to a fixed interest rate as per their Board approved policy. If the REs presently do not have any fixed interest rate product in any loan category, say home loan, then is it mandatory for the RE to introduce such a product?
faqs.answer: Yes, REs have to mandatorily offer a fixed interest rate product in all equated installment-based personal loan categories. As stated in paragraph 2(ii) of the circular, REs shall provide the option to the borrowers to switch over to a fixed rate as per their Board approved policy at the time of reset of interest rates.

faqs.question: Once the customer has exercised the option to switch over from floating interest rate loan to a fixed interest rate loan, as allowed vide paragraph 2(ii) of the circular, then is the RE required to give the option to the borrower to again switch back to a floating rate loan?
faqs.answer: Yes, the intent of the circular is to allow flexibility to the customer to switch from floating rate loan to fixed rate loan or vice versa subject to applicable charges. The RE is required to specify the number of times a borrower will be allowed to exercise the switch option during the tenor of the loan under its Board approved policy.

faqs.question: Whether the circular intends to cover only those loans which are linked to External Benchmark or the loans linked to Internal Benchmarks (Base Rate/MCLR/BPLR) also?
faqs.answer: It is clarified that the circular covers all equated installment-based personal loans, irrespective of whether they are linked to an external benchmark or an internal benchmark.

faqs.question: Whether the instructions in the circular allow REs to levy applicable charges for switching of loan from fixed interest rate to floating interest rate and vice versa?
faqs.answer: Yes, as stated in paragraph 2(iv) of the circular, REs can levy applicable charges for switching of loans from floating to fixed rate or vice versa and/or any other service charges/administrative costs incidental to the exercise of the switchover options. The same shall be transparently disclosed in the sanction letter and also at the time of revision of such charges/costs by the RE. The applicable charges shall be as approved by the board of the RE and shall be displayed on their website as per extant instructions.

faqs.question: Extant instructions applicable to UCBs allow for a maximum tenure of 20 years in case of housing loans. One of the options allowed vide paragraph 2(ii) of the circular is elongation of the tenor of the loan. Whether UCBs are allowed to extend the housing loan of the borrower for more than 20 years, during switch over from floating rate to fixed rate and vice versa or if the borrower opts for elongation of tenor for a floating rate loan, at the time of reset of interest rates?
faqs.answer: The options prescribed vide circular on ‘Reset of Floating Interest Rate on Equated Monthly Instalments (EMI) based Personal Loans’ dated August 18, 2023 shall be allowed for housing loans extended by UCBs, subject to the regulations prescribed vide Master Circular on ‘Housing Finance for UCBs’ dated April 11, 2023 or as amended in the future.

faqs.question: Will the circular be applicable to existing borrowers?
faqs.answer: Yes, the circular will be applicable to the existing borrowers.

faqs.question: What is UDGAM portal?
faqs.answer: UDGAM refers to Unclaimed Deposits-Gateway to Access inforMation, an online portal developed by RBI. It facilitates registered users to search unclaimed deposits/accounts across multiple banks in a centralized manner.

faqs.question: Are all banks part of the UDGAM portal? What percentage of the unclaimed deposits do they represent?
faqs.answer: No. As of March 4, 2024, 30 banks are part of the UDGAM portal, covering around 90% of unclaimed deposits (in value terms) in the Depositor Education and Awareness (DEA) Fund of RBI. The list of these banks is available on the UDGAM homepage and in the RBI Press Release dated October 5, 2023. The remaining banks are in the process of getting on-boarded.

faqs.question: What types of deposits/accounts are covered in the UDGAM portal?
faqs.answer: All unclaimed deposits/accounts that are part of the Depositor Education and Awareness (DEA) Fund of RBI can be searched in the UDGAM portal.

faqs.question: What inputs are required to search unclaimed deposits of individuals and non-individuals on UDGAM portal?
faqs.answer: A user must register on the portal by providing their name and mobile number. For individuals, the search requires the account holder's name, bank name(s), and at least one of the following: PAN, Driving License Number, Voter ID Number, Passport Number, or Date of Birth. For non-individuals, the search requires the entity’s name, bank name(s), and at least one of the following: Name of the authorized signatory, PAN, Corporate Identification Number (CIN), or Date of Incorporation. Alternatively, users can search using the address of the account holder or entity.

faqs.question: Can users settle or claim their unclaimed deposits through the UDGAM portal or from RBI?
faqs.answer: No, the UDGAM portal only facilitates searching for unclaimed deposits/accounts and provides information on the claim/settlement process of each bank. Unclaimed deposits can only be claimed from the respective bank.

faqs.question: What is Unclaimed Deposit Reference Number (UDRN)?
faqs.answer: UDRN is a unique number generated by banks' Core Banking Solution (CBS) and assigned to each unclaimed account/deposit transferred to the Depositor Education and Awareness (DEA) Fund of RBI. It ensures that the account holder or the bank branch cannot be identified by third parties. UDRN enables seamless claim settlement for customers who successfully search for their deposits on the UDGAM portal.

faqs.question: Who is an NRI?
faqs.answer: A ‘Non-resident Indian’ (NRI) is a person resident outside India who is a citizen of India.

faqs.question: Who is a PIO?
faqs.answer: A ‘Person of Indian Origin (PIO)’ is a person resident outside India who is a citizen of any country other than Bangladesh or Pakistan or such other country as may be specified by the Central Government, satisfying certain conditions, including being a former citizen of India, belonging to a territory that became part of India after August 15, 1947, or being a descendant of such individuals.

faqs.question: What are the major accounts that can be opened in India by a non-resident?
faqs.answer: The major accounts are: (1) Non-Resident (External) Rupee Account Scheme (NRE Account), (2) Foreign Currency (Non-Resident) Account Scheme [FCNR(B) Account], (3) Non-Resident Ordinary Rupee Account Scheme (NRO Account).

faqs.question: Can a Bangladeshi/Pakistani national or an entity owned/controlled from Bangladesh/Pakistan have an account in India?
faqs.answer: Individuals/entities of Pakistan and Bangladesh require prior approval from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). However, Bangladesh nationals holding a valid visa and residential permit may open an NRO account.

faqs.question: What accounts can a tourist visiting India open?
faqs.answer: A tourist visiting India can open an NRO (current/savings) account with funds remitted from outside India or from the sale of foreign exchange brought into India. The balance can be repatriated upon departure if the account was maintained for less than six months.

faqs.question: What is a SNRR account? How is it different from an NRO account?
faqs.answer: A Special Non-Resident Rupee (SNRR) account is for non-residents having a business interest in India. Unlike an NRO account, it is non-interest bearing and repatriable, while NRO accounts are primarily for local transactions and have repatriation restrictions.

faqs.question: What deposits can foreign Diplomatic missions/personnel and their family members in India hold?
faqs.answer: Foreign diplomatic missions, personnel, and family members can hold rupee deposits, Diplomatic Bond Stores Accounts, and foreign currency accounts with specific conditions.

faqs.question: Can persons resident in Nepal and Bhutan have accounts in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, they can open Indian rupee accounts with an authorized dealer in India.

faqs.question: Can a multilateral organization have deposits in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, any multilateral organization of which India is a member or its subsidiaries/affiliates can hold deposits with an authorized dealer in India.

faqs.question: Can an Indian company accept deposits from non-residents under Section 160 of the Companies Act, 2013?
faqs.answer: Yes, such deposits and refunds are covered under current account transactions and can be freely made without FEMA restrictions.

faqs.question: Can a Foreign Portfolio Investor or a Foreign Venture Capital Investor open a foreign currency account in India?
faqs.answer: Yes, registered Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs) and Foreign Venture Capital Investors (FVCIs) can maintain a non-interest bearing foreign currency account for investment purposes.

faqs.question: Who can open an Escrow Account in India and for what purpose?
faqs.answer: Resident and non-resident acquirers can open an Escrow Account in INR with an AD bank for capital instrument acquisitions or transfers, as per FEMA and related regulations.

faqs.question: What is meant by contravention and compounding of contravention?
faqs.answer: Contravention is a breach of the provisions of the Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA), 1999 and associated regulations. Compounding refers to voluntarily admitting the contravention, pleading guilty, and seeking redressal by paying a specified sum after a personal hearing.

faqs.question: Who can apply for compounding?
faqs.answer: Any person who contravenes any provision of FEMA, 1999 (except section 3(a)) or any related rule, regulation, notification, or condition can apply for compounding to the Reserve Bank. Applications related to section 3(a) contraventions should be submitted to the Directorate of Enforcement (DOE).

faqs.question: When should one apply for compounding?
faqs.answer: A person can apply for compounding upon becoming aware of a contravention, either suo moto or after receiving a Memorandum of Contraventions from the Reserve Bank or any statutory authority.

faqs.question: What is the procedure for applying for compounding?
faqs.answer: A contravener must submit a compounding application form physically or through the PRAVAAH Portal of the Reserve Bank, along with the necessary documents outlined in Annexures I, II, and III of the Directions – Compounding of Contraventions under FEMA, 1999.

faqs.question: Are any fees required to be paid for seeking compounding?
faqs.answer: Yes, a fee of ₹10,000 plus 18% GST must be paid via demand draft in favor of the Reserve Bank of India or through NEFT/RTGS. If the application is returned, the fee is non-refundable but does not need to be repaid if the application is re-submitted.

faqs.question: What details are required in the application form?
faqs.answer: The application must include details as per the relevant annexures, an undertaking confirming no ongoing DOE investigation, a canceled cheque, and a copy of the Memorandum of Association.

faqs.question: Where should one apply for compounding?
faqs.answer: The application should be submitted to the Reserve Bank as specified in the Directions – Compounding of Contraventions under FEMA, 1999.

faqs.question: Can an application for compounding be submitted before fulfilling obligations?
faqs.answer: No, all requisite approvals and compliances must be completed before seeking compounding.

faqs.question: What are sensitive contraventions?
faqs.answer: Sensitive contraventions involve serious offenses such as money laundering, terror financing, or threats to national security. These cases cannot be compounded by the Reserve Bank.

faqs.question: Is it mandatory to appear for the personal hearing?
faqs.answer: No, attending a personal hearing is optional. If an applicant chooses not to attend, the decision will be based on submitted documents.

faqs.question: Can the applicant authorize another person to attend the personal hearing?
faqs.answer: Yes, an authorized representative can attend with written authorization. However, RBI encourages applicants to attend directly.

faqs.question: How is the compounding process concluded?
faqs.answer: The Compounding Authority issues an order specifying the contravention and the payable amount. The process is concluded upon payment of the specified amount.

faqs.question: What is the criteria for calculating the compounding amount?
faqs.answer: The amount is determined based on the guidance in paragraph 5.4 of the Directions – Compounding of Contraventions under FEMA, 1999, considering various case-specific factors.

faqs.question: When should the compounding amount be paid?
faqs.answer: The amount must be paid within 15 days from the date of the order via demand draft or electronic transfer.

faqs.question: How does the application for compounding get disposed of?
faqs.answer: Once payment is made, a certificate is issued confirming compliance with the compounding order.

faqs.question: What happens if the amount is not paid within 15 days?
faqs.answer: Failure to pay within 15 days results in the case being treated as if no compounding application was made, and it may be referred to the Directorate of Enforcement (DOE) for further action.

faqs.question: Can there be an appeal against the order of the Compounding Authority?
faqs.answer: No, since compounding is voluntary, there is no provision for appeal or reduction of the imposed amount.

faqs.question: What is the timeframe for completing the compounding process?
faqs.answer: The process is completed within 180 days from the date of receipt of a complete application.

faqs.question: Where can one get more details about compounding?
faqs.answer: More details can be found in the Directions – Compounding of Contraventions under FEMA, 1999, available on the Reserve Bank's website.

faqs.question: Who is a person resident in India?
faqs.answer: A person resident in India, as per Section 2(v) of FEMA, 1999, is someone residing in India for more than 182 days during the preceding financial year, excluding those who have left India for employment, business, or other purposes indicating an indefinite stay abroad.

faqs.question: What is a foreign currency account?
faqs.answer: A Foreign Currency Account is an account held in a currency other than the Indian Rupee, Nepalese Rupee, or Bhutanese Ngultrum.

faqs.question: What are the major foreign currency accounts that can be opened in India by a resident individual?
faqs.answer: Resident individuals can open accounts such as Resident Foreign Currency (RFC) Account, Exchange Earners Foreign Currency (EEFC) Account, and Resident Foreign Currency (Domestic) [RFC(D)] Account, each with specific eligibility criteria and usage conditions.

faqs.question: In what form can a foreign currency account in India be opened?
faqs.answer: A foreign currency account in India can be maintained as a current, savings, or term deposit account for individuals, while for others, it can be held as a current or term deposit account.

faqs.question: When can a resident individual open a foreign currency account outside India?
faqs.answer: A resident individual can open a foreign currency account abroad when studying overseas, traveling, participating in trade fairs, receiving foreign salary payments, or remitting funds under the Liberalized Remittance Scheme (LRS).

faqs.question: Can a resident continue to maintain an account outside India which was opened by him when he was a non-resident?
faqs.answer: Yes, a resident can continue to hold a foreign currency account abroad if it was opened while they were a non-resident or if they inherited it from a person residing outside India.

faqs.question: What is the status of the account held outside India on the demise of the account holder?
faqs.answer: A resident nominee must close the foreign currency account and repatriate the funds to India through banking channels.

faqs.question: How is the Special Rupee Vostro Account (SRVA) different from the already existing Rupee Vostro Account?
faqs.answer: SRVA requires prior approval before opening, unlike the existing Rupee Vostro Account, and is part of an additional arrangement to facilitate trade settlement in INR.

faqs.question: What is new in this arrangement?
faqs.answer: This arrangement allows international trade to be settled in INR as a complementary system to existing settlements in freely convertible currencies, reducing dependence on hard currencies.

faqs.question: Is RBI approval required for opening Special Rupee Vostro Accounts?
faqs.answer: Yes, RBI approval is required. The AD bank must meet financial health and correspondent banking relationship criteria.

faqs.question: What is Correspondent banking?
faqs.answer: Correspondent banking involves one bank acting as an intermediary for another, facilitating wire transfers, deposits, and foreign transactions.

faqs.question: Is this a bank-to-bank arrangement or a country-to-country arrangement?
faqs.answer: This is primarily a bank-to-bank arrangement similar to a correspondent banking setup.

faqs.question: What is the procedure for opening a Special Rupee Vostro Account?
faqs.answer: AD banks must submit a request to RBI with details of the correspondent banking arrangement, due diligence confirmations, financial parameters, and compliance with FATF guidelines.

faqs.question: Can the Indian branch of a foreign bank open an SRVA for its head office or another branch abroad?
faqs.answer: Yes, provided the Indian branch is an AD bank and obtains RBI approval.

faqs.question: Can existing Rupee Vostro Accounts be converted into Special Rupee Vostro Accounts?
faqs.answer: No, existing Rupee Vostro Accounts cannot be used as SRVAs under this mechanism.

faqs.question: Can a foreign bank maintain multiple Special Rupee Vostro Accounts with different AD banks?
faqs.answer: Yes, a foreign bank can maintain multiple SRVAs with different AD banks.

faqs.question: Can an AD bank in India open multiple Special Rupee Vostro Accounts for banks from the same country?
faqs.answer: Yes, an AD bank in India can open multiple SRVAs for different banks from the same country.

faqs.question: How is the exchange rate determined?
faqs.answer: The exchange rate between trading partner currencies and INR will be market-determined.

faqs.question: How is the exchange rate determined if no direct quote exists for a currency pair?
faqs.answer: A cross-currency rate will be derived using the exchange rate of both currencies against global benchmarks like USD or EUR.

faqs.question: Is this mechanism designed to address cross-border payment issues with specific countries?
faqs.answer: No, this is a general policy to enhance the use of INR in international transactions.

faqs.question: Can balances in Special Rupee Vostro Accounts be repatriated?
faqs.answer: Yes, balances can be repatriated in freely convertible currency or the trading partner’s domestic currency, depending on the transaction type.

faqs.question: Can income from INR balances in SRVA be repatriated?
faqs.answer: Yes, subject to applicable regulatory guidelines and tax provisions.

faqs.question: Can balances in SRVA be used for FDI or ECB?
faqs.answer: Yes, SRVA balances can be used for any permissible current and capital account transactions under FEMA.

faqs.question: Where can surplus SRVA balances be invested?
faqs.answer: Funds can be invested in Government Treasury Bills, government securities, and other mutually agreed investments subject to compliance with regulatory guidelines.

faqs.question: Can INR balances in SRVA be hedged?
faqs.answer: Yes, INR exposure can be hedged per applicable guidelines based on underlying transactions.

faqs.question: Does a foreign bank need an FPI license to invest SRVA funds in T-Bills or government securities?
faqs.answer: No, an FPI license is not required.

faqs.question: Who is responsible for reporting cross-border transactions?
faqs.answer: The AD bank in India is responsible for reporting transactions in SRVA accounts.

faqs.question: How does this mechanism benefit Indian traders?
faqs.answer: Settlement in INR reduces exchange rate risk for Indian exporters and importers, making trade more predictable.

faqs.question: What are the processes to be adopted for transactions undertaken through SNRR Account?
faqs.answer: Payments initiated to the debit of SNRR Accounts must be communicated as SNRR transactions with purpose code and country details. Payments received for credit to SNRR Accounts must be confirmed as SNRR transactions. AD banks must ensure compliance with FEMA provisions for all such transactions.

faqs.question: Who is responsible for FEMA compliance for trade transactions?
faqs.answer: For debit to SNRR A/c (onward domestic credit), the AD bank handling export documents ensures compliance with export-related FEMA regulations. The AD bank maintaining the SNRR account performs due diligence on the overseas client and provides complete KYC details. For credit to SNRR A/c (received from a domestic account), the AD bank handling import documents ensures compliance with import-related FEMA regulations. In case of ECB, Trade Credits, or foreign investments, the designated AD bank ensures FEMA compliance, including FIRC issuance where applicable.

faqs.question: Does A2 reporting need to be undertaken by the bank remitting the funds?
faqs.answer: Yes, any domestic Indian party conducting a transaction that requires A2 reporting for an overseas remittance must undertake the same for a domestic remittance credited to an SNRR Account.

faqs.question: Is a purpose code required, and who is responsible for FETERS reporting?
faqs.answer: Yes, purpose codes are required. The AD bank maintaining the SNRR Account is responsible for FETERS (R Return) reporting. Transactions between an SNRR account and an offshore account of the non-resident entity will be reported under AD bank transfer. Transactions between an SNRR account and a domestic Indian party will be reported based on the underlying transaction.

faqs.question: Are ACU guidelines applicable to shipments to ACU countries?
faqs.answer: Yes, trade transactions with ACU countries must be settled under the ACU mechanism as per FEMA Notification 14 (R) and extant instructions, and must be kept separate from the SNRR arrangement.

faqs.question: Can interest be earned on SNRR balances or through term deposits?
faqs.answer: No, interest cannot be earned on SNRR balances or through term deposits.

faqs.question: In which month of the year, the ITES survey is launched by the RBI?
faqs.answer: The RBI launches the ITES survey during the month of June every year with the previous financial year end-March as the reference date.

faqs.question: What is the frequency of this ITES survey?
faqs.answer: Annual.

faqs.question: What is the timeline for the submission in ITES Survey?
faqs.answer: The respondent companies/LLPs/proprietorship firms can submit their responses on or before July 15 of every year.

faqs.question: What is the reference period of this ITES survey?
faqs.answer: The reference period of an ITES survey round is the immediately preceding financial year (April-March).

faqs.question: What information should be reported in ITES survey, if balance sheet of the company is not audited before the due date of submission?
faqs.answer: If the company’s accounts are not audited before the due date of submission, i.e. July 15, then the ITES survey schedule should be submitted based on unaudited (provisional) account.

faqs.question: In case where account closing period of the company is different from reference period (end-March), can it report the information as per account closing period?
faqs.answer: No. Even if a company’s account closing period is different from reference period (end-March), the ITES survey information should be reported for the survey reference period, based on the company’s internal assessment.

faqs.question: Which entities are required to participate in the ITES survey?
faqs.answer: Companies/LLPs/Partnership firms in the business of export of computer software & information technology enabled services are required to participate in this survey.

faqs.question: Whether ITES survey schedule is required to be submitted by LLPs/proprietorship firms, who have computer software export during the reference period? If yes, then what is the procedure to submit the survey schedule?
faqs.answer: Since the access to the submission portal is CIN based, any LLP/proprietorship firm that have computer software exports as on end-March of the financial year needs to obtain a dummy CIN Number by sending a request mail on itesquery@rbi.org.in. Once the firm obtains this dummy CIN number from RBI, it can be used to submit the excel (*.xls) file for ITES survey.

faqs.question: What information on business activity classification has been covered under this survey?
faqs.answer: Four major business activities of computer software & information technology enabled services with their sub-classifications are covered under the survey schedule. Details can be found in the survey schedule itself.

faqs.question: If the company/LLPs/proprietorship firm does not have export earnings during the reference period, does it need to participate in the survey?
faqs.answer: Yes. In case the company/LLPs/proprietorship firm doesn’t have export earnings during the reference period, but had the same earlier, then it has to submit NIL survey schedule for the current round of ITES survey.

faqs.question: What is the invoicing currency to be reported for exports?
faqs.answer: Total invoice value must be in Indian Rupees (INR) in actuals (which should also include billing to subsidiary(s)/associate(s)) during the reference period.

faqs.question: What is the reporting currency in invoice value in Export-major currencies?
faqs.answer: Total invoice value must be in Indian Rupees (INR) in actuals (which should also include billing to subsidiary(s)/associate(s) abroad) during the reference period.

faqs.question: What is the reporting of currency in invoice value in Export-Type of services?
faqs.answer: Total invoice value must be in Indian Rupees (INR) in actuals (which should also include billing to subsidiary(s)/associate(s) abroad) as per type of export service.

faqs.question: What is the reporting of currency in invoice value in Export-Major Areas?
faqs.answer: Total invoice value in Indian Rupees (INR) in actuals (including billing to subsidiary(s)/associate(s) abroad) during the reference period to major countries/regional groups.

faqs.question: If two or three units of a company are located in India and another unit is located outside India say in UK, then should they participate separately in the ITES survey?
faqs.answer: Company has to submit only one form aggregating all the units in India. However, for the units abroad, the information should be provided in Part D of the schedule.

faqs.question: Should the number of employee information be reported as on end of March of the reference year?
faqs.answer: Yes, the number of employee information should be reported as on end-March of the reference year.

faqs.question: If a company offers services to develop a product for another company in abroad then where should it mention this information in ITES survey schedule?
faqs.answer: Company has to mention percentage of this service under ‘Offshore product development’ in Q-3 (D) of Part-A and consolidated amount under Q-5 (a-iv) for software products.

faqs.question: Which type of expenses should be covered under “total amount spent on office expenses etc. abroad (excluding amount paid to employees abroad) by the Indian company” in Q-7 (iii) of Part-B?
faqs.answer: Office expenses include all the expenses incurred in running the office abroad during the year like internet payment, stationery, etc. If the office has been set up outside India in the reference period (say 2023-24) then that will also be included.

faqs.question: Which amount is to be considered in “Total amount held abroad at the beginning of the reference period by the Indian company” in Q-7 (iv) of Part-B?
faqs.answer: Total amount held abroad at the beginning of the reference period would mean the outstanding amount that is to be received from abroad (for the exports made) at the beginning of reference period i.e., April 2023-March 2024 (refers to 'as on April 01, 2023').

faqs.question: Which amount is to be considered in the Q-7(v) of Part-B in the ITES survey schedule?
faqs.answer: The amount held abroad is the outstanding amount which is yet to be received by the company from the importers i.e. unpaid amount for the exports made by the company.

faqs.question: The Invoice value includes all the amounts billed to customer, but all the invoice bills are not received in the reference period. Does this mean the actual (realised) amount received within the reference period?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is the amount actually received (realised) during the reference period including the billing to subsidiaries/associates abroad.

faqs.question: Is it required to fill the declaration at the end of the ITES survey schedule?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is mandatory. The person authorised to fill the form owns the responsibility of information furnished and declares its accuracy including CIN number.

faqs.question: Which entities are eligible to report under CPIS?
faqs.answer: Presently, banks, mutual fund companies, non-financial companies, non-banking financial companies, and insurance companies are surveyed under the CPIS.

faqs.question: What is the frequency of the survey?
faqs.answer: The survey is conducted half-yearly in India for capturing the end-March and end-September position of the latest financial year (FY).

faqs.question: Should AIFs report under CPIS?
faqs.answer: Yes, since AIFs are considered under non-banking financial institutions.

faqs.question: How do I know that the survey is launched?
faqs.answer: The Reserve Bank sends emails to all eligible entities from generic email IDs of the Reserve Bank to notify them about the launch of the CPIS.

faqs.question: How do I know whether my response has been submitted successfully or not?
faqs.answer: After sending the duly filled survey schedule, the respondent will receive a system-generated acknowledgment.

faqs.question: What is the launch timeline of the CPIS?
faqs.answer: The CPIS is launched for end-March and end-September positions on June 01 and December 01 of that year respectively.

faqs.question: What is the due date for participating in CPIS?
faqs.answer: The due date for CPIS participation is July 15 for end-March data and December 31 for end-September data.

faqs.question: What if the reporting entity does not receive the soft copy of the survey schedule by email?
faqs.answer: Entities can download it from the RBI website or request it via email.

faqs.question: Should we report data for a particular branch of the reporting entity or the consolidated data of the entity?
faqs.answer: A consolidated data at the entity level, covering all branches/offices in India, should be furnished.

faqs.question: What information should be reported under CPIS?
faqs.answer: The survey collects details of portfolio investment assets of domestic residents made in securities issued by unrelated non-residents.

faqs.question: At what value should the portfolio investment assets be reported?
faqs.answer: They should be reported on a marked-to-market basis as at the end of the reference period, with breakups into types of securities and country of issuer.

faqs.question: What is the unit of reporting the data in CPIS?
faqs.answer: Entities should report data in the unit mentioned in the survey schedule (e.g., INR Lakh).

faqs.question: If the responding entity does not have any portfolio investment assets during the reference period, do they need to participate in the survey?
faqs.answer: Yes, they must submit a NIL survey schedule.

faqs.question: What information should be reported if the balance sheet of the entity is not audited before the due date of submission?
faqs.answer: They should report based on unaudited (provisional) accounts.

faqs.question: What to report in equity securities?
faqs.answer: Equity consists of instruments that acknowledge claims on the residual value of a corporation or quasi-corporation.

faqs.question: What should be considered under equity securities?
faqs.answer: This includes ordinary shares, stocks, participating preference shares, shares in mutual funds, depository receipts, and more.

faqs.question: What should not be included under equity securities?
faqs.answer: Non-participating preference shares, equity issued by related non-residents, and securities acquired under reverse repos.

faqs.question: What to report in debt securities?
faqs.answer: Debt securities are negotiable instruments serving as evidence of a debt, including bonds, notes, and money market instruments.

faqs.question: What are long-term debt securities?
faqs.answer: These are debt securities with an original maturity of more than one year, including bonds, debentures, and notes.

faqs.question: What are short-term debt securities?
faqs.answer: These have an original maturity of one year or less, including treasury bills, negotiable certificates of deposit, and commercial paper.

faqs.question: At what value should we report securities - face value or market value?
faqs.answer: Equity and debt securities should be reported at market prices converted to domestic currency using the prevailing exchange rate.

faqs.question: What is the method that can be used for approximating market prices for equity securities?
faqs.answer: Methods include recent transaction price, net asset value, price-to-earnings ratio, market capitalization method, and more.

faqs.question: Whom to contact in case of any query related to CPIS?
faqs.answer: Queries can be directed to the RBI at International Investment Position Division (IIPD), Department of Statistics and Information Management (DSIM), Mumbai.

faqs.question: Should portfolio investment assets made by branches of the banks outside India be included in CPIS?
faqs.answer: No, investments made by branches outside India should not be included.

faqs.question: Should portfolio investment assets made by branches of your bank located in the IFSC zone of India to the rest of the world be included in CPIS?
faqs.answer: Yes, they should be included.

faqs.question: Should portfolio investment assets made by branches of your bank located in non-IFSC zones of India to other branches located in the IFSC zone be included in CPIS?
faqs.answer: No, they should not be included as they are considered resident-to-resident transactions.

faqs.question: What is Digital Rupee?
faqs.answer: Digital Rupee or eRupee, is India’s Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC). It is the digital form of India’s physical currency, the Rupee (₹). eRupee is issued by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in digital form and offers features similar to physical cash like convenience of use, guarantee of RBI, finality of settlement, etc.

faqs.question: How can eRupee be held and used?
faqs.answer: eRupee can be held and transacted through eRupee wallets offered by banks and non-banks for person-to-person payments or person-to-merchant transactions. Users can download the eRupee app from the Play Store or the App Store and follow the app instructions.

faqs.question: What is an eRupee Wallet?
faqs.answer: eRupee wallet is a digital wallet that stores Digital Rupee, similar to a physical wallet/purse storing cash. It is currently provided by banks and non-banks participating in the retail CBDC pilot.

faqs.question: Are eRupee wallets safe?
faqs.answer: Yes, eRupee wallets are safe and secure. There is a robust cybersecurity framework to ensure security. Even if a mobile device is lost, the wallet can be recovered using the same phone number/SIM on a new device.

faqs.question: Which mobile operating system platform does eRupee wallet currently support?
faqs.answer: eRupee wallet is available and supported on both Android and iOS mobile devices.

faqs.question: How is Digital Rupee created and issued?
faqs.answer: RBI creates and issues eRupee electronically to banks and non-banks, which then distribute it to users via eRupee wallets.

faqs.question: Who can use eRupee?
faqs.answer: Currently, users and merchants of identified pilot banks and non-banks can use eRupee by downloading the eRupee app and registering for an eRupee wallet.

faqs.question: Can Digital Rupee be transacted from one’s bank account outside banking hours?
faqs.answer: Yes. eRupee can be loaded/redeemed/transferred 24/7 from/to a bank account.

faqs.question: Is there any minimum balance required to open/maintain an eRupee wallet?
faqs.answer: No. There is no minimum balance required to open or maintain an eRupee wallet.

faqs.question: Is a savings account mandatory for retail customers to use eRupee?
faqs.answer: Currently, opening an eRupee wallet is linked to the user’s savings account for seamless onboarding and KYC compliance.

faqs.question: Why do I see eRupee with different denominations in the wallet?
faqs.answer: For ease of use, eRupee is available in the same denominations as physical currency to provide familiarity and convenience.

faqs.question: How can one transact without having the required denomination or change?
faqs.answer: The eRupee wallet provides the required change automatically. For example, if a user has only ₹20 but needs to pay ₹15, the wallet will return ₹5 in change.

faqs.question: Are there any charges/fees for using eRupee?
faqs.answer: No, there are no charges or fees associated with using eRupee or eRupee wallets.

faqs.question: Will interest be paid on the ₹ balances in the eRupee wallet?
faqs.answer: No. Similar to physical cash, no interest is paid on eRupee balances.

faqs.question: Is eRupee legal tender?
faqs.answer: Yes, eRupee is legal tender under Section 26 of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Act, 1934, and is guaranteed by the Central Government.

faqs.question: Is there any difference between eRupee and UPI?
faqs.answer: Yes. eRupee is a digital form of currency, whereas UPI is a means of transferring money. eRupee can act as a ‘store of value’ and be used independently of a bank account.

faqs.question: What is the offline feature of eRupee?
faqs.answer: The offline feature allows transactions in areas with limited or no internet connectivity. Different offline solutions are currently being tested.

faqs.question: What is the programmability feature of eRupee?
faqs.answer: Programmability allows funds in eRupee wallets to be used for specific purposes, such as Direct Benefits Transfer (DBT) schemes, employee allowances, or government subsidies.

faqs.question: Which are the pilot banks currently offering CBDC wallets?
faqs.answer: Currently, 15 banks are offering CBDC wallets, including SBI, ICICI Bank, HDFC Bank, Axis Bank, and others.

faqs.question: What is a Wholesale CBDC and how does it differ from Retail CBDC?
faqs.answer: Wholesale CBDC (eRupee-W) is designed for financial institutions to streamline interbank settlements and large-value transactions. Retail CBDC (eRupee-R) is meant for the general public for everyday transactions.

faqs.question: What are the potential benefits of eRupee-W?
faqs.answer: eRupee-W can enhance the efficiency, speed, and security of financial transactions, reducing settlement risks through programmability and smart contracts.

faqs.question: Which are the participants in the wholesale CBDC pilot?
faqs.answer: Currently, 14 banks and financial institutions are participating in the wholesale CBDC pilot.

faqs.question: What are the current use cases in eRupee-W and what are the benefits?
faqs.answer: Ongoing use cases include settlement of secondary market transactions in Government Securities and interbank call money market lending, reducing costs and mitigating settlement risks.

faqs.question: In which month does RBI launch the MF survey?
faqs.answer: The RBI launches the MF survey during the month of June every year with the previous financial year ended end-March as the reference date.

faqs.question: What is the frequency of this survey?
faqs.answer: The survey is conducted annually.

faqs.question: Which entities are required to participate in the survey?
faqs.answer: MF companies in India are required to participate in this survey.

faqs.question: How does the MF company submit the MF survey schedule to the RBI?
faqs.answer: Once the survey is launched, MF companies receive an email from RBI along with the soft copy of the survey schedule (Schedule-4) in excel format. The filled-in survey schedule should be sent by email to mf@rbi.org.in.

faqs.question: What if the MF company does not receive the soft copy of the survey schedule by email?
faqs.answer: MF companies can download Schedule-4 from the RBI website or send a request to mfquery@rbi.org.in.

faqs.question: What is the timeline for submission in MF Survey by Mutual Fund companies?
faqs.answer: Mutual fund companies can submit their responses on or before July 15 of every year.

faqs.question: What is the timeline for submission in MF Survey by Asset Management Companies (AMCs)?
faqs.answer: AMCs must submit their annual return on Foreign Liabilities and Assets (FLA) through RBI’s online web-based portal ‘FLAIR’ by July 15 of every year.

faqs.question: How does an AMC report data/submit the FLA return to the RBI?
faqs.answer: Entities can submit the annual return on FLA through the online portal at https://flair.rbi.org.in.

faqs.question: What is the reference period of MF survey?
faqs.answer: The reference period is the immediately preceding financial year (April-March).

faqs.question: If the MF company/AMCs does not have foreign liabilities and assets during the reference period, do they need to participate in the survey?
faqs.answer: Yes, they must submit a NIL survey schedule of MF survey as well as FLA form on the FLAIR portal.

faqs.question: Can a company get an acknowledgment for submission of the MF survey schedule?
faqs.answer: Yes, after submitting the survey schedule to mf@rbi.org.in, the MF company will receive a system-generated acknowledgment.

faqs.question: What information should be reported in MF survey, if the balance sheet of the company is not audited before the due date of submission?
faqs.answer: If the company’s accounts are not audited before July 15, the MF survey schedule should be submitted based on unaudited (provisional) accounts.

faqs.question: If the account closing period of the MF company/AMCs is different from the reference period (end-March), can it report the information as per account closing period?
faqs.answer: No, the MF survey information should be reported for the reference period, based on the company’s internal assessment.

faqs.question: What is a budget?
faqs.answer: Put simply, it is a plan of your future income and expenses. Budgets can be yearly, monthly or even weekly.

faqs.question: Why prepare a budget at all?
faqs.answer: With a budget in hand, you will be able to control your expenses better and save more. Comparing the budget with the actual expenditure will show where you spent more (or less).

faqs.question: What is Saving?
faqs.answer: Saving can be defined as: Saving = Income - Expenditure or Expenditure = Income - Saving. You should set aside a portion of your income BEFORE you spend anything.

faqs.question: Where to Save?
faqs.answer: The three important things that one must keep in mind while saving are Safety, Liquidity, and Return.

faqs.question: What is Safety in Saving?
faqs.answer: Safety depends on how certain/guaranteed return of your principal amount or investment is. Government Bonds are the safest. Bank Fixed Deposits are also considered comparatively safe.

faqs.question: What is Liquidity in Saving?
faqs.answer: Liquidity depends on how easy it is to sell an asset with minimum loss in value. Bank Deposits, listed and traded Equity Shares, and Mutual Funds are considered comparatively more liquid.

faqs.question: What is Return in Saving?
faqs.answer: Return depends on the type of financial product and the risk associated with it. Equity shares may give higher returns but also carry higher risk of loss.

faqs.question: What points should be kept in mind when saving?
answer: Make sure that your savings are invested in diversified instruments.
Some portion should be in liquid assets so that you can withdraw money when needed.
Do not put your money in instruments that are very risky/unregulated, you may lose all of it!

faqs.question: What is Responsible Borrowing?
faqs.answer: One should borrow to invest in assets that create value or generate returns. Examples of good borrowing are mortgage loans to buy a house, education loan for funding children’s higher education, etc.

faqs.question: Whom to borrow from?
faqs.answer: It is advisable to borrow from regulated entities like banks, NBFCs, and HFCs.

faqs.question: What are Deposit Accounts and their types?
faqs.answer: Deposit accounts can be categorized as Passive vs. Active Savings. Regular savings bank accounts fetch very low rates of interest, hence can be termed passive savings. Instead, investing in Recurring/Fixed Deposits of banks fetches better returns.

faqs.question: What are some good banking practices?
answer: Taking a passbook/statement of account & checking entries periodically.
Keeping cheque-book (if taken) in safe custody.
Not sharing Internet Banking (if availed) ID & password with anyone.
Not sharing debit card (if obtained) PIN with anyone.
Not sharing OTPs (one-time passwords) received for carrying out online transactions with anyone.

faqs.question: What is nomination and why nominate?
faqs.answer: A nominee is the person who is entitled to receive the money lying in the bank account (as a trustee of the legal heir/s of the deceased depositor) after the death of the depositor in a single account and death of all depositors in case of a joint account. Nomination helps in quick settlement of claims and reduces hardship for surviving family members. Always fill up the nomination form when you open a bank deposit account. Approach your bank to update your nomination details.

faqs.question: What is Premature Withdrawal?
faqs.answer: Fixed Deposits are normally for a particular/specified period of time. If you want to withdraw the amount before the end of the period, then the bank will charge a penalty for premature withdrawal. Always opt for a premature withdrawal mandate, anytime during the tenure of term deposits (with joint account holders), for hassle-free claim settlement. In the event of the depositor’s death, premature withdrawal would not attract any penal charge.

faqs.question: What exactly is a Credit Score?
answer: A Credit Score (a three-digit number) indicates a borrower’s creditworthiness and is typically based on their credit history and other factors.
It is given along with a Credit Information Report issued by a Credit Information Company.
Credit Score would be higher if the borrower has always repaid loans taken from banks/financial institutions on time.

faqs.question: Why is Credit Score important?
answer: Banks/Financial institutions ascertain/check your credit score and credit history, along with other factors, while sanctioning your loans.
All other things remaining the same, a borrower with a higher credit score will usually be able to borrow at a lower rate of interest.

faqs.question: What is a Free Annual Credit Report?
faqs.answer: Individuals have access to their one free full credit report (FFCR) including credit score, once a calendar year. Information on the procedure to access FFCR is available on websites of respective credit information companies (CICs).

faqs.question: How can inaccuracies in the Credit Information Report (CIR) be corrected?
faqs.answer: In case of any inaccuracy in CIR, a borrower may request the CIC/credit institution (banks/NBFCs, etc.) to correct/update their CIR. If the complaint remains unaddressed for more than thirty days or the borrower is not satisfied with the resolution, the complainant may approach the RBI-Ombudsman by filing a complaint on https://cms.rbi.org.in.

faqs.question: How can you improve your Credit Score?
answer: Borrow only within your means; i.e., only so much as you can repay regularly & on time.
Make sure you do not miss any repayment installment.
Repay loans earlier if possible, as it creates good credit history.

faqs.question: What is an Inoperative Account?
faqs.answer: A savings/current account shall be treated as inoperative if there are no ‘customer-induced transactions’ in the account for over two years.

faqs.question: Why are inoperative accounts segregated from other accounts?
faqs.answer: Inoperative accounts are segregated from other accounts to reduce the risk of frauds and to bring to the attention of dealing bank staff the increased risk in the account.

faqs.question: Is the mandate for crediting interest on Fixed Deposits and/or dividends on shares treated as a customer-induced transaction?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is treated as a customer-induced transaction.

faqs.question: What is the process for activating an inoperative account?
answer: Banks have been advised to make available the facility of KYC updation for activation of inoperative accounts/unclaimed deposits at all branches (including non-home branches) and through Video-Customer Identification Process (V-CIP) if requested by the account holder.
Customers can approach the nearest bank branch for activation.

Banks must activate the inoperative account within three working days, adhering to KYC guidelines prescribed by RBI such as Customer Due Diligence (CDD), customer identification, and risk categorization.

Banks are also required to automatically intimate inoperative account/unclaimed deposit holders through SMS and registered email stating that, based on the KYC documents submitted, the inoperative status of the account has been removed.

faqs.question: Are there any charges for activation of an inoperative account?
faqs.answer: No, there are no charges for the activation of an inoperative account.

faqs.question: Is interest paid on inoperative savings bank accounts?
faqs.answer: Yes, interest on savings bank accounts is credited on a regular basis irrespective of whether the account is operative or not. If a Fixed Deposit Receipt matures and proceeds are unpaid, the amount left unclaimed with the bank shall attract the rate of interest applicable to the savings account or the contracted rate of interest on the matured fixed deposit, whichever is lower.

faqs.question: Is information on inoperative accounts available on the bank’s website?
answer: Banks must display the list of unclaimed deposits/inoperative accounts which are inactive/inoperative for ten years or more on their respective websites.
A search facility is also provided by banks for the public to search the list of accounts by the name of the account holder.

Customers can also use the search facility provided by RBI on the UDGAM portal (https://udgam.rbi.org.in/unclaimed-deposits/#/login) to search for their unclaimed deposits transferred by banks to RBI’s Depositor Education and Awareness (DEA) Fund.
This search facility is presently available for 30 banks as listed here (https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_PressReleaseDisplay.aspx?prid=56498).

faqs.question: What is the time value of money?
faqs.answer: The time value of money (TVM) is the concept that money available now is worth more than the same amount of money available in the future due to its potential earning capacity, provided the rate of interest is positive. ₹100 today may not be equivalent to ₹100 to be received after two years. If money is not invested wisely, it can lose value due to inflation. If the return on an investment of ₹100 is say 5% and the inflation rate is 7%, then the real return is (-2%)! Money has lost value to the extent of ₹2. To compensate for inflation and other factors, financial institutions pay interest if you deposit money and charge interest if you borrow money. It is essential to save and invest in appropriate financial products to earn a rate of return above the rate of inflation to preserve the future value of money.

faqs.question: What is risk and return?
faqs.answer: Any investment entails a certain degree of risk. Generally, there is a direct correlation between risk and return. The higher the expected return, the higher the risk (including the possibility of losing the initial investment as well). And lower the return, lower the risk as well.
