The basic investment principle to be kept in mind while investing or saving in financial products is the risk vs. return trade-off. High expected returns may entail higher risk and the possibility of potential losses. Invest your money wisely! Beware! High and quick return schemes could be risky. Do not chase returns without understanding the risks! Thoroughly check the background and performance of the entity offering the scheme. Read the terms and conditions carefully. Do your study and due diligence before being lured by ‘Too Good To Be True’ schemes of unknown entities!

faqs.question: What are retail remittances?
faqs.answer: NEFT, RTGS, and IMPS are the most popular remittance channels offered by banks to transfer money. They can be availed at the bank branch or through online channels like Internet banking, mobile banking, etc., offered by your bank.

faqs.question: What is UPI?
faqs.answer: Unified Payments Interface or UPI is a platform that allows transfer of money between two bank accounts using a smartphone that has access to the internet. You can use the BHIM app, any bank’s app, or any third-party app for facilitating UPI transactions.

faqs.question: How does UPI work?
answer: You need a bank account, a mobile number linked to that bank account, and a smartphone with internet connection.
To facilitate feature phone users to avail benefits of UPI, UPI123Pay was launched with four options: App-based functionality, Missed Call, IVR, and Proximity Sound-based payments.
A debit card linked to the account is required one time for setting up UPI on a mobile phone.
UPI can also be linked to RuPay Credit Cards.

faqs.question: How to activate UPI?
answer: Download the App on your smartphone and link your bank account, then create a UPI PIN by following the instructions given in the App.
Using your UPI PIN, you can transfer funds seamlessly to any beneficiary by just knowing their virtual address or UPI number.
If the beneficiary doesn’t have a virtual address or UPI number, you can transfer funds using IFSC and the bank account number.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of UPI?
answer: Can send and receive money instantly.
Can transfer money 24/7, 365 days even on holidays and Sundays using a smartphone.
Use of a virtual ID makes it easy to transfer money and obviates the need to share sensitive bank account information.

faqs.question: What are some precautions with respect to UPI?

Dos: Always review the merchant/person’s collect request before accepting it.
Recheck and re-confirm the amount and beneficiary before effecting the transfer.
Don’ts: Never share your UPI PIN with anyone.
Refrain from transferring money without verifying/reconfirming the recipient first.

faqs.question: What are some precautions regarding online and mobile banking?

Dos: Always type your bank’s URL using only verified and trusted browsers and HTTPS secured websites for payments (S stands for Secure). Look for a secure sign (lock) in the URL window.
Make your passwords difficult to guess by using alphanumeric and special characters (#, *, @, $ etc.).
Ensure that you change your password frequently.
Always keep your payment transaction Apps (banks, non-banks, Wallets etc.) updated with the latest version.
Link your mobile number and email ID with your bank account and opt for SMS/e-mail alert service.
In case of any unusual/unauthorised transaction, inform the bank immediately.
Don’ts: Never access your bank’s website through online search.
Never store login credentials on your phone, also don’t enter/store credentials on untrusted portals/service providers.
Avoid transacting through public devices, cyber cafes, and unsecured/open networks like public/free WiFi.
Never share your mobile banking PIN, Internet banking ID, password, or OTP with anyone (including bank staff).

faqs.question: What are some precautions regarding ATM transactions?

Dos: Ensure that you use only EMV Chip and PIN based Debit Card instead of a card with a magnetic strip (Approach your bank for replacing the magnetic strip card).
Ensure that there are no unauthorized cameras or other skimming devices near ATMs when you key in your PIN or swipe your cards.
Make sure no one sees the PIN when it is being entered at the ATM. It is a good practice to cover the keypad with one hand and use the other hand to key in your PIN.
Remember to count and check the notes dispensed.
Remember to collect your card after the transaction is over.
Register your phone number with the card-issuing bank to get alerts on ATM transactions.
Contact your bank immediately to block the card if it gets lost or stolen or if you feel it has been compromised.
Don’ts: Do not share your ATM card details (card number, expiry date, CVV etc.) and PIN with anyone.
Never leave the Card in the ATM.
Never share your OTP with anyone.
Never write your PIN on the Card.

faqs.question: Are the deposits in banks safe?
faqs.answer: Yes, up to the limit insured, the deposits are safe. Your deposits are insured by Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation (DICGC), a wholly owned subsidiary of the RBI.

faqs.question: Which banks are covered under deposit insurance?
faqs.answer: Commercial banks (Private Sector Banks, Public Sector Banks, Foreign Banks in India, Local Area Banks, Small Finance Banks, Payment Banks, Regional Rural Banks) and cooperative banks (State Cooperative Banks, District Central Cooperative Banks, Urban Cooperative Banks) registered with DICGC are insured. Obtaining deposit insurance cover is mandatory for all banks licensed by RBI.

faqs.question: Which deposits are covered under DICGC?
faqs.answer: DICGC insures all types of deposits (e.g., Savings, Fixed, Recurring, etc.) with an insured bank but does not include deposits received from a Foreign Government, the Central Government, a State Government, another bank, or any deposit received outside India. Each depositor in a bank is insured up to a maximum of ₹5 lakh for both principal and interest amount held by them in the 'same right and same capacity'.

faqs.question: Do I need to pay a premium for DICGC insurance?
faqs.answer: No, you do not have to pay any premium. The DICGC charges a nominal premium from the banks. Unlike other bank fees, this premium is not charged to you.

faqs.question: What will happen to my deposits if the bank is liquidated by RBI?
faqs.answer: If a bank goes into liquidation, DICGC is liable to pay to each depositor, through the liquidator, the total amount of their deposit (in the same capacity and in the same right) as on the date of deregistration of the bank, up to a maximum limit of ₹5 lakh.

faqs.question: What will happen to my deposits if my bank is placed under 'All Inclusive Directions' (AID) by RBI?
faqs.answer: Once an insured bank is placed under 'All Inclusive Directions' (AID) by the Reserve Bank of India with restrictions on withdrawal of deposits, DICGC is liable to pay to each depositor the total amount of their deposit (in the same capacity and in the same right) as on the date of issue of direction/prohibition to the bank, up to a maximum limit of ₹5 lakh. The depositors of such banks are advised to contact the respective bank officials, submit the form on willingness including alternate bank details and other necessary documents immediately to enable the banks to submit the list of depositors’ claims up to the insured amount before the cut-off date given to the bank by DICGC.

faqs.question: How will I know the status of my claim?
faqs.answer: Depositors of liquidated banks and AID banks will receive an SMS intimation at each stage of claim settlement i.e., on receipt of claim and on sanction of claim.

faqs.question: Is DICGC active on any social media?
faqs.answer: DICGC regularly posts public awareness messages and information regarding payment to depositors of AID banks on the ‘Public App’ by Inshorts for wider dissemination of information among the general public.

faqs.question: When to approach the RBI Ombudsman?
faqs.answer: For redress of grievance, the complainant must first approach the concerned RE. If the complaint lodged with the RE is not redressed / no reply is received within a period of 30 days, or, if the complainant is not satisfied with the reply given by the RE, the complainant can lodge the complaint with the RBI Ombudsman.

faqs.question: Where to lodge a complaint with RBI?
faqs.answer:
Complaints can be lodged with the RBI Ombudsman / CEPC through:
1. Online at https://cms.rbi.org.in/
2. Letter/post to 'Centralised Receipt and Processing Centre, 4th Floor, Reserve Bank of India, Sector-17, Central Vista, Chandigarh-160017'.

faqs.question: Is there any charge or fee to be paid for filing a complaint with the RBI Ombudsman?
faqs.answer: No. There is no charge or fee for filing or resolving complaints under the RB-IOS, 2021. Complaints can be registered by individuals free of cost without the need for third-party agencies.

faqs.question: What are the advantages of filing complaints online at the CMS portal?
answer: Simplified and cost-free method of filing the complaint.
Complaint can be filed from anywhere in the country.
Automatic acknowledgement upon registration.
Facility for real-time tracking of complaint status.
Facility for online submission of additional documents.
Facility for submitting feedback on the redressal process.

faqs.question: How to know more about lodging a complaint with RBI?
faqs.answer: Individuals can contact the RBI Contact Centre via toll-free number 14448 for guidance on grievance redressal and complaint filing. The service is available on all working days in Hindi, English, and ten regional languages.

faqs.question: Can complaints be filed through the RBI Contact Centre?
faqs.answer: No, complaints cannot be filed through the Contact Centre. However, it assists complainants in filing complaints through the CMS portal or physical mode.

faqs.question: How does relief from calamities work?
answer: Central or State Government notifies a natural calamity in your area.
SLBC or DCC announces relief measures for affected borrowers.
Borrowers may approach their bank/NBFC to restructure or recast existing loans or request fresh loans.
Loans may be restructured with benefits like moratorium period, enhanced repayment period, relaxed KYC norms, and interest subvention benefits.

faqs.question: What are some safety tips regarding digital lending applications?
answer: Before using any digital lending app, check whether it is associated with an RBI-regulated bank/NBFC.
Avoid downloading apps received via SMS or social media links.
Report suspicious loan apps to law enforcement agencies.
Assess the total loan cost, including Annual Percentage Rate and other terms, before borrowing.
Read all loan-related documents carefully, including Key Fact Statements and privacy policies.
Check data storage policies of digital lenders before granting app permissions.
In case of grievances, contact the grievance redressal officer of the bank/NBFC or escalate to the CMS portal under RBI-Integrated Ombudsman Scheme.

faqs.question: What is a useful platform for visually impaired persons to identify currency notes?
faqs.answer: Visually impaired individuals can use the MANI App, which identifies the denomination of Indian currency notes using audio notifications in multiple languages and vibration mode. The app is available for free on Android and iOS platforms.

faqs.question: How to exchange soiled/mutilated/defective notes?
answer: Soiled, torn, damaged, mutilated, or defective notes can be exchanged at bank branches over the counter.
Banks follow the RBI Note Refund Rules, 2009 (amended in 2018) for exchanging notes.
If a bank refuses to exchange notes, a complaint can be lodged with the bank.
If unresolved for a month, the complaint can be escalated to the RBI Ombudsman.

faqs.question: What is income?
faqs.answer: Money earned from various sources like salary, wages, earnings from farming or business, etc., is our income.

faqs.question: What is expenditure?
faqs.answer: Money spent on various items is our expenditure. It includes spending money on both essential and non-essential items.

faqs.question: What is investment?
faqs.answer: Investment is the deployment of money, usually from savings, with the expectation of earning higher returns over time. Examples include purchasing land, fixed deposits in banks, etc.

faqs.question: What is saving?
faqs.answer: When income is more than expenses, the surplus money is known as savings.

faqs.question: What is debt?
faqs.answer: When expenses exceed income and there are no savings, money is borrowed to cover the shortfall, creating debt.

faqs.question: How to manage debt?
faqs.answer: If expenses exceed income in a particular month, savings from previous months can be used to cover the shortfall. If there are no savings, borrowing becomes necessary, leading to debt.

faqs.question: What is the difference between essential and non-essential items of expenditure?
faqs.answer: Essential items are basic needs like food, shelter, clothing, education, and healthcare. Non-essential items are wants, which are desirable but not necessary for survival.

faqs.question: How can we manage our money?
faqs.answer: We can manage our money efficiently by financial planning. The first step is maintaining a financial diary to track income and expenses over a period, such as a week or a month.

faqs.question: What is financial planning?
faqs.answer: Financial planning involves estimating financial needs and ways to meet them throughout life. It includes planning for child education, home purchase, marriage, medical emergencies, and unexpected events like accidents or natural calamities.

faqs.question: Why should we do financial planning?
faqs.answer: Financial planning helps in saving regularly for future needs and controlling unnecessary expenses. It ensures better financial stability and allows individuals to build savings for major life goals.

faqs.question: How to do financial planning?
answer: Assess current financial position.
Identify short-term (1 year), medium-term (1-5 years), and long-term (more than 5 years) financial goals.
Estimate the cost of each goal and set a savings plan.
Maintain a financial diary to track income and expenses.
Curb unnecessary expenses.
Regularly review savings and make adjustments if needed.
Deposit savings in a bank account for security and interest.

faqs.question: Why maintain a financial diary?
faqs.answer: A financial diary helps in tracking income and expenses, identifying avoidable costs, and increasing savings. It prevents overspending and helps break the cycle of poverty.

faqs.question: How can we reduce expenses?
faqs.answer: Expenses can be reduced by cutting down on non-essential spending and making judicious choices. For example, reducing daily tea consumption from 4 to 2 cups can save ₹300 per month, leading to ₹3,600 savings in a year.

faqs.question: What is the key financial principle to follow?
answer: Needs are limited – Spend wisely.
Wants are unlimited – Reduce unnecessary expenses.
Vices are risky – Avoid spending on harmful habits.

faqs.question: Why should we save?
answer: To meet higher expenses such as birth, education, marriage, purchasing farm seeds, purchasing own house, etc.
To cover unexpected expenses like illness, accident, death, or natural calamities.
To have money available during lean periods when we are unable to earn.
To secure our old age and retirement.
To afford things that cannot be purchased from regular income.

faqs.question: How to save?
answer: By cutting down on unnecessary expenses.
By increasing our income.
Avoiding spending on vices like drinking, gambling, and excessive festival expenses.
Reducing non-essential expenditures such as luxurious goods or entertainment.
Postponing big purchases like TVs, scooters, or jewelry.

faqs.question: How can we save when we do not have enough money even to meet our regular expenses?
answer: Start saving a small amount regularly, even if it is minimal.
Set aside a portion of earnings from the beginning.
Save unexpected earnings or profits instead of spending them.
A small daily saving habit can add up to significant savings over time.

faqs.question: For how long should we save?
faqs.answer: The longer we save, the more our savings will grow, ensuring financial security in emergencies and old age.

faqs.question: Where to save?
answer: Keeping money at home can be unsafe and unproductive.
Banks provide a secure place to save money with added benefits like interest earnings.

faqs.question: Why save in a bank?
answer: Money is safe as banks are regulated.
Banks offer interest on deposits, helping money grow.
Easier access to financial services such as loans and remittances.
Transparent transactions and records.
Nomination facility ensures smooth transfer of funds after death.

faqs.question: What is nomination?
faqs.answer: Nomination allows a depositor to designate a person who can claim the account balance after their death, ensuring easy fund transfer.

faqs.question: What are the advantages of having a bank account?
answer: Provides an identity recognized by government agencies.
Ensures transparency in financial transactions.
Offers security for savings.
Enables receipt of wages, pensions, and government benefits directly.
Allows easy deposits, withdrawals, and remittances.
Access to loans and credit facilities.

faqs.question: What is EBT?
faqs.answer: Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) is the digital transfer of social security benefits like pensions, wages, and subsidies directly into bank accounts.

faqs.question: What is remittance?
faqs.answer: Remittance is the transfer of money from one place to another, which can be done safely and efficiently through banks.

faqs.question: What is interest?
answer: Interest is the extra amount earned on savings or the cost paid on borrowed money.
Banks pay interest on deposits and charge interest on loans.

faqs.question: What are different types of deposit accounts?
answer: Savings Deposit - Allows withdrawals anytime and earns interest.
Term Deposit - Fixed period deposit with higher interest.
Recurring Deposit - Regular deposits over time to accumulate savings.

faqs.question: How can we open a savings bank account?
faqs.answer: By filling out an account opening form and submitting identity and address proof as per KYC requirements.

faqs.question: What is a Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account?
faqs.answer: A no-minimum balance savings account with free deposits, withdrawals, passbook, and ATM/smart card facilities.

faqs.question: What is KYC?
faqs.answer: Know Your Customer (KYC) is a process where banks verify identity and address proof before opening accounts.

faqs.question: What is BC (Business Correspondent)?
faqs.answer: A BC is an agent appointed by banks to provide banking services in areas without bank branches, using mobile banking devices.

faqs.question: What is an Overdraft?
faqs.answer: An overdraft is a small loan facility linked to a savings account for emergency financial needs without separate documentation.

faqs.question: What is the difference between income and credit?
faqs.answer: Income is money earned, while credit (loan) must be repaid with interest and should not be treated as earnings.

faqs.question: When should we borrow?
answer: When expenditure exceeds income and there are no savings.
For productive purposes like business investments.
In emergencies when there is no other option.

faqs.question: Should we always borrow whenever short of money?
answer: No, borrowing for unnecessary expenses like festivals or luxury items should be avoided.
Loans should be taken only when repayment is possible from future income.

faqs.question: Why is it advisable to borrow only for income-generating activities?
faqs.answer: Borrowing should be for activities that increase earnings so that loans can be repaid without financial strain.

faqs.question: Why borrow within limits?
faqs.answer: Borrow only an amount that can be repaid comfortably without financial burden.

faqs.question: Why take a loan from a bank when informal sources like money lenders are readily available in the village?
answer: Banks are safer, more reliable, and transparent institutions regulated by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).
Banks charge lower interest rates than informal sources like moneylenders, vishi, mukhiya, etc.
Banks provide proper documentation for loans, ensuring clarity and fairness.
In case of disputes, banks offer a Grievance Redressal Mechanism.

faqs.question: What is the Grievance Redressal Mechanism of banks?
answer: Every bank has a Grievance Redressal Officer whose details are published in bank branches and websites.
Complaints can be lodged with the bank’s Grievance Redressal Officer.
If not satisfied with the resolution, complaints can be escalated to the Banking Ombudsman of RBI.

faqs.question: Is similar Grievance Redressal Mechanism available in case of formal sources?
faqs.answer: No, informal sources do not have a grievance redressal mechanism, making them less transparent and riskier.

faqs.question: Why do banks sometimes take longer to give loans compared to money lenders?
answer: Banks lend depositors’ money and must ensure proper utilization by borrowers.
Banks conduct detailed scrutiny before sanctioning loans to protect depositors' funds.
Though the process takes longer, it ensures fairness and prevents fraud.

faqs.question: What are the types of loans offered by banks?
answer: Housing loans
Education loans
Agriculture and related activity loans
Business enterprise loans
Consumption loans

faqs.question: How can I get a loan from a bank?
answer: Submit a loan application indicating the purpose of the loan.
The bank verifies details and evaluates the repayment capacity.
If approved, the loan is sanctioned and must be repaid in installments with interest.

faqs.question: What is the cost of borrowing from banks?
answer: Interest charged on borrowed money is the cost of borrowing.
Banks transparently display interest rates and charges, which are uniform for all customers.
Unlike informal lenders, banks disclose real borrowing costs upfront.

faqs.question: Do we have to offer some guarantee for the loan?
answer: Small loans may not require a guarantee.
Higher amounts may require collateral such as land, house, or assets created using the loan.

faqs.question: Why should we repay the loan?
answer: Banks use depositors' money for lending; non-repayment weakens the bank’s financial position.
Repaying loans ensures banks can return depositors' money on time.
Only if we repay loans, banks will sanction us loans in the future.

faqs.question: What if we do not repay the loan taken from the bank?
answer: The bank has the right to take possession of the security offered as collateral.
The bank can initiate legal proceedings to recover the loan amount along with interest.

faqs.question: What is the difference between needs and wants?
answer: Needs are essential for survival, such as food, shelter, and clothing.
Wants are non-essential and can be postponed or avoided, such as luxury items or entertainment.

faqs.question: What is budgeting?
answer: Budgeting is the process of balancing income and expenses to ensure that expenses are always less than income.
It helps in saving and investing for future needs.

faqs.question: What are the common sources of borrowing?
answer: Banks and financial institutions
Non-Banking Financial Institutions
Friends and family

faqs.question: What are the main types of bank accounts?
answer: Savings Account: Offers interest on deposits and has limited withdrawals.
Current Account: Meant for businesses with no restrictions on deposits and withdrawals.

faqs.question: Can minors open a savings account?
answer: Yes, a minor can open a savings account with a guardian.
Minors above 10 years can independently operate a savings account.

faqs.question: What are recurring deposits (RDs)?
answer: Recurring Deposits allow fixed monthly deposits for a specified period.
The total amount, along with interest, is repaid at the end of the term.

faqs.question: What are fixed deposits (FDs)?
answer: Fixed Deposits are made for a particular period ranging from 7 days to 10 years.
The interest rate depends on the term and amount of the deposit.
Withdrawals before maturity may be allowed with penalties.

faqs.question: What are the different types of loans offered by banks?
answer: Personal Loan: Used for emergencies like medical or marriage expenses.
Vehicle Loan: Provided for purchasing a vehicle, which remains hypothecated to the bank.
Home Loan: Helps individuals buy homes with long-term repayment options.
Education Loan: Funds higher studies and is repaid after course completion.
Agricultural Loan: Supports farmers in purchasing equipment and seeds.

faqs.question: What is investment?
answer: Investment is the allocation of money into assets with the expectation of earning returns over time.
Common investments include land, stocks, mutual funds, and fixed deposits.

faqs.question: What is a mutual fund?
answer: A mutual fund pools money from multiple investors and invests in securities.
It helps in diversification, reducing risk, and providing professional fund management.
Mutual funds are regulated by SEBI (Securities and Exchange Board of India).

faqs.question: What are the types of mutual fund schemes?
answer: Growth/Equity-Oriented Scheme: Focuses on long-term capital appreciation with higher risks.
Income/Debt-Oriented Scheme: Aims to provide steady income by investing in fixed-income securities.

faqs.question: What is insurance?
answer: Insurance is a financial arrangement that provides protection against unforeseen risks like accidents, illness, and death.
It includes life insurance and general insurance (health, vehicle, property, etc.).

faqs.question: What is the National Pension System (NPS)?
answer: NPS is a government-backed pension scheme aimed at providing financial stability during retirement.
It is open to all citizens aged 18-60 and requires a minimum yearly saving of Rs. 500.

faqs.question: What is Vidya Lakshmi?
answer: Vidya Lakshmi (https://www.vidyalakshmi.co.in) is a government portal for students seeking education loans.
It allows students to apply to multiple banks through a single platform.

faqs.question: Who regulates the financial sector in India?
answer: Reserve Bank of India (RBI): Regulates monetary policy and banking.
Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI): Regulates stock markets and securities.
Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI): Regulates the insurance sector.
Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA): Regulates pension funds.

faqs.question: What are the functions of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI)?
answer: Issues currency and ensures adequate supply of genuine notes.
Acts as a banker to the government and banks.
Regulates monetary policy to maintain price stability and economic growth.
Ensures financial stability by supervising the banking system.

faqs.question: Can entrepreneurs get loans without collateral?
answer: Yes, under the Credit Guarantee Fund Trust for Micro and Small Enterprises (CGTMSE) scheme, entrepreneurs can get loans without collateral.
The scheme is a joint initiative of the Ministry of MSME and SIDBI to provide credit to MSEs without the need for collateral or third-party guarantees.

faqs.question: Where can entrepreneurs find more details about collateral-free loans?
answer: Entrepreneurs can visit www.cgtmse.in and www.dcmsme.gov.in for more information about the CGTMSE scheme before applying for a loan.

faqs.question: What is the General Credit Card (GCC)?
answer: GCC is a facility that provides credit to non-farm entrepreneurs for both working capital and term loan requirements.
It is issued as a smart card or debit card and can be used at ATMs and swipe machines.
The borrowing limit and interest rates are determined by the bank.

faqs.question: What are the steps in the loan application process?
answer: Step 1: Prepare a business plan and funds requirement estimate.
Step 2: Apply online at https://udyamimitra.in/ or visit a bank directly.
Step 3: Get a loan application number and acknowledgment.
Step 4: Respond to queries from the bank and track the application for approval or rejection.

faqs.question: What are the BCSBI-prescribed timelines for loan applications?
answer: For MSE loan applications up to Rs. 5 lakhs: 2 weeks.
For credit limits above Rs. 5 lakhs and up to Rs. 25 lakhs: 3 weeks.

faqs.question: What is the difference between financing with own capital and taking a loan?
answer: When financing with own capital, all profits remain with the entrepreneur but growth may be slower.
Taking a loan allows expansion and business growth but requires interest payments and timely repayments.

faqs.question: What is cash credit against hypothecation of stock?
answer: Cash credit is a type of loan where a business borrows against self-liquidating security like stock.
The business only withdraws the amount needed, and interest is charged only on the outstanding amount.

faqs.question: What is receivables financing?
answer: Receivables financing allows businesses to get loans based on payments expected from customers (debtors).
The bank provides finance after deducting a margin, and interest is charged only on the outstanding amount.

faqs.question: What is depreciation, and why is it important?
answer: Depreciation is the reduction in the value of a fixed asset over time due to wear and tear.
It helps businesses allocate the cost of an asset over its useful life and ensures proper financial reporting.

faqs.question: What are term loans?
answer: Term loans are long-term loans taken for specific purposes, such as purchasing fixed assets.
They are repaid in installments over a period of time, typically more than one year.

faqs.question: What should entrepreneurs do if their business is under financial stress?
answer: They should proactively approach their bank or the district-level committee for financial restructuring or additional support.
Options include rectification, restructuring, or recovery, depending on the viability of the business.

faqs.question: What is the Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS)?
answer: TReDS is a platform where entrepreneurs can discount their receivables to address delayed payments from buyers.
Entities like RXIL, Mynd Solution, and A.TReDS operate the platform under RBI regulations.

faqs.question: What are Certified Credit Counsellors (CCCs)?
answer: CCCs are professionals registered by SIDBI who assist entrepreneurs in preparing business proposals and maintaining financial documents.
A list of CCCs is available at https://udyamimitra.in/Home/CCC.

faqs.question: What is the KYC requirement for opening a savings bank account for a Self-help Group (SHG)?
answer: KYC verification of all SHG members is not required; only the office-bearers need to undergo KYC verification.
A resolution authorizing office-bearers to open the account on behalf of the SHG must be submitted.

faqs.question: How is the loan amount determined for an SHG?
answer: The bank may sanction a loan based on the SHG’s total corpus.
Generally, the loan amount can be 1 to 4 times the corpus.
If the corpus is Rs. 10,000, the loan can be between Rs. 10,000 and Rs. 40,000.

faqs.question: Is collateral required for SHG loans?
answer: No, banks are not required to obtain collateral security for loans given to SHGs.

faqs.question: Can SHGs receive loans greater than four times their corpus?
answer: Yes, if the SHG has been functioning successfully for many years, has repaid past loans on time, and has used credit facilities responsibly.

faqs.question: What are the types of savings contributions in an SHG?
answer: SHG members contribute compulsory savings at periodic meetings.
Members can also voluntarily contribute additional savings beyond the fixed amount.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of voluntary savings in SHGs?
answer: Voluntary savings can be kept separately or added to the group corpus.
If added to the group corpus, it increases the SHG’s eligibility for higher loans from banks.

faqs.question: What are the key principles of SHGs regarding periodic meetings?
answer: Meetings should be held regularly, preferably weekly, but can also be fortnightly or monthly.
Regular attendance strengthens the SHG and helps members understand each other’s challenges.

faqs.question: Why is periodic savings important for SHGs?
answer: Regular savings help build a strong common fund, reducing dependence on moneylenders.
A higher group corpus allows members to meet their financial needs through internal lending.

faqs.question: What is internal lending in SHGs?
answer: Once an SHG accumulates enough savings, members can borrow against their savings for emergencies or income-generating activities.
The group decides the loan amount, interest rate, and repayment schedule.

faqs.question: Why is regular loan repayment important in SHGs?
answer: Timely repayment maintains trust and creditworthiness.
Delayed payments result in higher interest costs and poor credit scores, making future borrowing difficult.

faqs.question: What is a credit score, and why is it important for SHG members?
answer: A credit score is a numerical representation of a person’s creditworthiness, ranging from 300 to 900.
Higher scores indicate better repayment history, making it easier to access future loans.

faqs.question: Why is bookkeeping important for SHGs?
answer: It ensures transparency and builds trust among members.
It helps assess the financial health of the group, track savings, loans, and repayments.
Proper records enhance the SHG’s creditworthiness and make it eligible for loans from banks.

faqs.question: What is meant by financial literacy?
faqs.answer: Financial literacy is providing knowledge and skills to poor people to help them make informed decisions about expenditures, savings, investments, credit, insurance, and financial services such as remittances and pensions.

faqs.question: What is the need for financial literacy in Self-help Groups (SHGs)?
faqs.answer: SHGs work towards poverty alleviation and development of poor families by providing financial services such as savings, credit, and insurance. Financial literacy helps SHG members make informed decisions about managing money effectively.

faqs.question: How is financial literacy related to poverty alleviation?
faqs.answer: Poor financial decisions can lead to exploitation, high-interest loans, asset loss, child labor, and health risks. Financial literacy helps people take better financial decisions, preventing them from falling deeper into poverty.

faqs.question: How is financial management done in a family?
faqs.answer: Financial management in a family involves setting aside money from income, taking loans when needed, and buying assets. Poor families have limited choices and must plan their finances carefully to meet financial goals.

faqs.question: What are needs and wants?
faqs.answer: Needs are essential for survival, such as food, water, and shelter. Wants are things that improve life but are not essential, such as a television or motorbike.

faqs.question: What are the different types of needs?
answer: Lifecycle Needs: Weddings, funerals, childbirth, education, house construction, and old age.
Personal Emergencies: Sickness, injury, unemployment, theft, or death.
Disasters: Fires, floods, cyclones, war, and eviction.
Investment Opportunities: Expanding a business, buying land, or improving housing.

faqs.question: How do people fulfill their financial needs?
faqs.answer: Poor people use creative ways like saving livestock, grains, and jewelry. They may save up before making purchases or borrow and repay after meeting the need.

faqs.question: What is the difference between saving, credit, and insurance?
answer: Saving: Setting aside money regularly for future needs.
Credit: Spending upfront and repaying in small amounts later with interest.
Insurance: Paying premiums to cover uncertain risks and losses.

faqs.question: Why should saving be regular and continuous?
faqs.answer: Regular savings reflect financial discipline and creditworthiness. It helps in financial planning and ensures funds are available for emergencies and future needs.

faqs.question: How can one save?
faqs.answer: Savings can be in cash or kind (grains, fiber, oil, seeds). It should be planned as the first expenditure of the household, ensuring savings align with financial goals.

faqs.question: How much should one save?
faqs.answer: Savings depend on individual needs, expenses, and income. A minimum of 25% of household income should ideally be saved for future needs.

faqs.question: Where should we save?
answer: Informal methods: Keeping money at home, local chits, informal groups.
Formal methods: Post office savings, commercial banks, and SHGs for secure savings with potential for loans.

faqs.question: What criteria should be considered when choosing a savings product or institution?
answer: Safety and security of money.
Proximity to the saver’s location.
Potential returns and preservation of value.
Ease of depositing and withdrawing money.
Availability of credit facilities linked to savings.

faqs.question: What are the savings schemes available in commercial banks?
answer: Savings Bank Account: Meant for individuals who wish to deposit small amounts and earn interest.
Recurring Deposit Account: Requires fixed periodic deposits for a specified period, accumulating interest.
Fixed Deposit Account: A lump sum deposit for a fixed period earning higher interest.
Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account: A no-frills account for low-income individuals with no minimum balance requirement.

faqs.question: What documents are required to open a savings bank account?
answer: Identity proof: Passport, PAN card, Voter ID, Aadhaar, Driving License, etc.
Address proof: Utility bills, Bank statements, Employer letter, Ration card, etc.

faqs.question: What is a Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account?
answer: Eligibility: Individuals earning Rs. 5,000 per month or less.
No minimum balance requirement.
Limited withdrawals allowed per month.
ATM-cum-debit card provided without charge.

faqs.question: What are the savings products available in SHGs?
answer: Regular Savings: Members contribute a fixed amount regularly, similar to a bank savings account.
Diversified Savings: Similar to recurring deposits, where members save for specific planned needs.
Current Savings: Allows frequent deposits and withdrawals without earning interest.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of saving in an SHG?
answer: Savings are managed by the members themselves.
Convenient doorstep saving facility.
Members decide interest rates and loan disbursement rules.
Higher savings lead to larger loans from banks.

faqs.question: What are the savings schemes available in the Post Office?
answer: Post Office Savings Account: Functions like a bank savings account with easy withdrawals.
Post Office Recurring Deposit: Regular fixed deposits for a period, earning interest.
Post Office Time Deposit: Similar to a bank fixed deposit, earning higher interest for longer terms.

faqs.question: How to open a Post Office Savings Account?
answer: Minimum deposit of Rs. 20 is required.
Accounts can be opened individually or jointly.
Depositor introduction is necessary for account opening.

faqs.question: Why do people need credit?
answer: When they do not have money during emergencies (e.g., sickness, death of cattle).
When they experience a deficit cash flow in a specific period (e.g., dairy farmers needing funds during dry periods).
When they need money to invest in a business or income-generating activity.
When they are affected by disasters such as droughts or floods.

faqs.question: Where do people get credit?
answer: Money lenders
Friends and relatives
Associations and societies
Commercial and cooperative banks
Self-help Groups (SHGs)

faqs.question: Where should poor households avail credit from?
faqs.answer: For small consumption and livelihood needs, poor households can take credit from SHGs, while for larger enterprise loans, they can approach commercial and cooperative banks.

faqs.question: What are the loan products available in commercial and cooperative banks?
answer: Short-term loans (Demand loans)
Long-term loans (Term loans for agriculture, education, business, housing, etc.)
Cash credit
Overdraft facilities

faqs.question: What is a short-term loan?
faqs.answer: A short-term loan, also known as a demand loan, is repayable on demand or at short notice. The entire amount is disbursed at once, and the borrower can repay in lump sum or as agreed with the bank.

faqs.question: What is a long-term loan?
faqs.answer: A long-term loan is granted for more than one year, usually between 5 to 15 years, for purposes such as agriculture, housing, education, or business expansion. Repayment is done in fixed installments.

faqs.question: What is cash credit?
faqs.answer: Cash credit is an arrangement where the bank allows a borrower to withdraw funds up to a certain limit. Interest is charged only on the amount drawn, not on the total limit.

faqs.question: What is an overdraft facility?
faqs.answer: An overdraft facility allows a current account holder to withdraw money beyond their available balance. Interest is charged on the amount used, and repayment is flexible.

faqs.question: What is the cost of credit, and how is interest charged on loans?
answer: Interest rates on loans vary between formal institutions (banks) and informal sources (money lenders).
Flat rate: Interest is charged on the total loan amount throughout the loan period.
Diminishing balance: Interest is charged only on the remaining principal balance, making it more affordable.

faqs.question: How do SHGs provide credit to their members?
answer: SHGs offer credit for various needs, such as emergencies, housing, and small businesses.
Loan eligibility, interest rates, and repayment schedules are decided by the SHG.
SHGs prioritize responsible lending and repayment.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of availing credit from SHGs?
answer: Low interest rates
Simple and easy loan procedures
Flexible repayment schedules
No transaction costs as loans are provided at the doorstep
Building creditworthiness for future bank loans

faqs.question: What factors should be considered when choosing a source of credit?
answer: Timely availability of credit
Low interest rates
Simple loan application process
Proximity to the lender
Flexible repayment terms
Minimal documentation requirements

faqs.question: What is credit discipline and why is it important?
faqs.answer: Credit discipline refers to using borrowed funds for the intended purpose and repaying loans on time. It helps in building trust with banks and ensures continued access to credit.

faqs.question: What happens if loans are not repaid on time?
faqs.answer: Unpaid loans become Non-Performing Assets (NPA), making it difficult for banks to lend money. It also affects the borrower’s creditworthiness and future borrowing ability.

faqs.question: What is insurance?
faqs.answer: Insurance is a form of risk management that protects against financial loss due to unexpected events like illness, accidents, or death.

faqs.question: Why is insurance important for poor households?
faqs.answer: Poor households face risks like illness, natural disasters, and loss of earning members. Insurance provides financial protection and prevents them from falling deeper into poverty.

faqs.question: How can poor people buy insurance?
answer: Through group insurance policies offered by SHGs.
Corporate agency model: SHGs collaborate with insurance companies to provide coverage.
Mutual solutions: SHG members contribute collectively to manage risks.

faqs.question: What are the different types of insurance products available?
answer: Life insurance
Health insurance
Livestock insurance
Crop insurance

faqs.question: What is life insurance?
faqs.answer: Life insurance provides financial support to the family of the insured person in case of their death or critical illness. Policies like Janashree Bima Yojana offer coverage to poor households.

faqs.question: What is health insurance?
faqs.answer: Health insurance covers medical expenses, including hospitalization. The Universal Health Insurance Scheme provides coverage for poor households.

faqs.question: What is livestock insurance?
faqs.answer: Livestock insurance protects farmers from financial loss due to the death of cattle or other livestock.

faqs.question: What is crop insurance?
faqs.answer: Crop insurance protects farmers from financial loss due to natural disasters like droughts or floods. The Varsha Bima scheme provides coverage for anticipated rainfall shortfalls.

faqs.question: How can farmers buy crop insurance under the Varsha Bima scheme?
faqs.answer: Farmers can enroll through Rural Financial Institutions (RFIs), SHGs, and NGOs. The insurance covers crop loss due to insufficient rainfall.

faqs.question: What role do NGOs play in providing insurance to poor households?
answer: Ensuring that poor people receive benefits from government social security schemes.
Helping SHG members enroll in contributory insurance schemes like Janashree Bima Yojana.

faqs.question: What is pension?
faqs.answer: Pension is a type of insurance that provides income security to individuals in their old age. Unlike life insurance, which covers the financial risks associated with death, pension covers the financial risks associated with living longer.

faqs.question: Why is pension important?
answer: The number of elderly people is increasing worldwide, with India set to have nearly 198 million elderly individuals by 2030.
Many elderly people, especially those from the unorganized sector, do not have access to social security schemes.
Pension ensures financial stability for aged individuals, reducing economic struggles and dependency.

faqs.question: What pension products are available for the poor in India?
answer: Micro pension product of UTI
Pension products from LIC (e.g., Jeevan Nidhi, Jeevan Akshay, New Jeevan Dhara-I, New Jeevan Suraksha-I)
NPS-Lite (National Pension System for economically disadvantaged individuals)

faqs.question: What is NPS-Lite?
answer: NPS-Lite is a pension scheme regulated by the Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA) for individuals from the economically disadvantaged sections of society.
It allows individuals to contribute small amounts during their earning years and receive a pension after retirement.
It is a low-cost pension option with regulated investment norms.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of joining NPS-Lite?
answer: Voluntary participation for Indian citizens aged 18-60.
Affordable with contributions as low as Rs.100 per month.
Portable across India, allowing individuals to maintain their pension accounts even when relocating.
Safe and regulated by PFRDA.
Optimized for low-income individuals with ultra-low costs.

faqs.question: What role do NGOs play in enabling pension schemes for the poor?
answer: Identifying social security programs for the poor and ensuring their enrollment.
Assisting in documentation and application for pension schemes.
Educating individuals on the importance of pension and financial planning for old age.

faqs.question: What is remittance?
faqs.answer: Remittance refers to the transfer of money from one person to another. It can be a simple money transfer (e.g., sending money to family) or a transfer for making payments (e.g., salary payments).

faqs.question: Why is remittance important for low-income households?
answer: Many workers migrate for seasonal employment and need to send money back to their families in rural areas.
Remittances help meet household consumption needs and support investments in agriculture and small businesses.
Lack of formal remittance options forces many people to rely on informal and expensive methods of money transfer.

faqs.question: What are the formal ways of sending remittances in India?
answer: Bank money transfers (including electronic and paper-based transactions).
Postal remittance services (e.g., Money Orders, Instant Money Orders).
Business Correspondents (BCs) facilitating remittance services.
Mobile banking transactions through banks and telecom companies.

faqs.question: What are the informal ways of sending remittances?
answer: Sending money through friends and family traveling home.
Using informal agents or couriers who charge a commission for money delivery.
Hawala system, where intermediaries facilitate cross-border or local money transfers without formal banking involvement.

faqs.question: How do banks facilitate remittance transfers?
answer: Paper-based systems such as cheques and demand drafts.
Electronic systems like Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS), Electronic Clearing System (ECS), and National Electronic Funds Transfer (NEFT).
ATM/debit/credit card-based money transfers.

faqs.question: How does postal remittance work in India?
answer: India Post provides money transfer services through Money Orders and Instant Money Orders.
Recipients receive money at their doorstep or collect it from the post office.
Although reliable, postal remittances can sometimes take time to process.

faqs.question: How does mobile banking help in remittances?
answer: Banks allow customers to transfer money using mobile phones, reducing the need for physical bank visits.
Transactions can be done through SMS-based services or mobile banking apps.
Mobile banking is cost-effective and secure, reducing dependency on cash transactions.

faqs.question: What is the transaction limit for mobile banking in India?
answer: A daily limit of Rs. 50,000 per customer for fund transfers and purchases.
For cash disbursement via ATMs or Business Correspondents, the limit is Rs. 5,000 per transaction.

faqs.question: What is the role of Business Correspondents (BCs) in remittances?
answer: BCs act as intermediaries between banks and unbanked individuals.
They provide mobile banking solutions to enable money transfers in remote areas.
They help individuals open bank accounts and facilitate financial transactions.

faqs.question: What are the risks of using informal remittance channels?
answer: Higher costs due to commissions charged by agents.
Lack of security and risk of fraud or robbery.
Delays in money transfer and lack of proper documentation.

faqs.question: Why should people use formal remittance channels?
answer: Security: Money transfers are legally protected and regulated.
Affordability: Formal channels like banks and postal services have lower transaction costs.
Reliability: Transactions are recorded, and funds reach recipients safely.

faqs.question: What is the need for Business Correspondents (BCs) and Business Facilitators (BFs) in India?
answer: Despite various initiatives such as nationalization of banks, Regional Rural Banks (RRBs), and the SHG-Bank linkage program, a significant portion of the rural population still lacks access to banking services.
Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) cover only 18.4% of the rural population through savings accounts and 17.2% through loan accounts.
Primary Agricultural Credit Societies (PACS) have a wide presence but limited impact in providing financial services.
Barriers to banking include high transaction costs, lack of collateral, inadequate financial literacy, and the absence of banking infrastructure in rural areas.
Informal lending sources, such as moneylenders, continue to dominate due to their doorstep availability and ease of access.

faqs.question: What is meant by a Business Facilitator (BF)?
answer: A Business Facilitator is an intermediary appointed by banks to assist in financial services delivery without conducting actual banking transactions.
They can include NGOs, Farmer Clubs, cooperatives, community-based organizations, post offices, insurance agents, and well-functioning Panchayats.
Their role involves identifying borrowers, collecting loan applications, creating financial awareness, promoting Self-Help Groups (SHGs), and monitoring loan repayments.

faqs.question: What are the key functions of a Business Facilitator?
answer: Identifying borrowers and assessing their credit needs.
Collecting and verifying loan applications.
Creating awareness about financial products and debt management.
Submitting processed applications to banks.
Promoting and supporting SHGs and Joint Liability Groups (JLGs).
Post-sanction monitoring and loan recovery follow-ups.

faqs.question: What is meant by a Business Correspondent (BC) model?
answer: Under the Business Correspondent model, certain organizations and individuals are authorized to conduct banking transactions on behalf of banks in areas without physical bank branches.
BCs can be NGOs, MFIs, cooperatives, NBFCs (not accepting public deposits), post offices, or section 25 companies.
BCs facilitate financial inclusion by providing doorstep banking services to the underserved population.

faqs.question: What are the key functions of a Business Correspondent?
answer: Disbursing small-value credit to customers.
Collecting loan repayments and interest.
Accepting small-value deposits.
Selling micro-insurance, mutual funds, pension products, and other third-party financial services.
Facilitating small-value remittances and other payment instruments.

faqs.question: How do Business Correspondents differ from Business Facilitators?
answer: Business Facilitators (BFs) provide support services like borrower identification, financial literacy, and loan monitoring but do not handle financial transactions.
Business Correspondents (BCs) conduct actual banking transactions such as loan disbursement, deposit collection, and payment services.
BCs act as an extended arm of banks, whereas BFs primarily assist in financial outreach and literacy.

faqs.question: Why are Business Correspondents important for financial inclusion?
answer: BCs help reach unbanked rural and remote populations by providing financial services at their doorstep.
They enable small-value transactions, which banks often find unprofitable to handle through traditional branches.
They reduce reliance on informal lenders by providing affordable credit and savings options.
BCs improve financial literacy and encourage formal banking habits among low-income households.

faqs.question: What are the benefits of the Business Correspondent model for banks?
answer: Expands the reach of banks without the need for opening physical branches.
Reduces operational costs while increasing financial inclusion.
Enables efficient micro-lending and small-scale financial transactions.
Helps in achieving regulatory financial inclusion targets set by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).
